. I am a serjeant in the Coldstream Guards - I was not at Leeds at this time; I know the prisoner, and have seen him write frequently; the body of this draft is the prisoner's writing - I do not know whose the signature is; I cannot say whether the writing on the back of it is his.
Cross-examined. Q. How long has he been in the regiment? A. About fourteen years - he had generally a good character, but he deserted in October last.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Then if Captain Hope had given him drafts before that, would he have ceased to do so after he had deserted? A.Certainly; if the name of
James Compton
on the back of this draft is the prisoner's writing, it is disguised.

ALFRED WILSON
. I am clerk to Cox, Greenwood and Co. This draft was presented from Brown, Janson and Co., and I paid it on the 5th of January; I concluded that the name
James Hope
on it was genuine.
Cross-examined. Q. Can you say why it should be presented and paid at Leeds? A. I believe it is a very common thing for persons to go to bankers in the country, and get cash for drafts.

THE HON. CAPTAIN
JAMES HOPE
. I am a captain in the army , and lieutenant in the Coldstream Guards . The body of this draft is certainly the prisoner's writing; the signature I do not know - it is not my writing.

Cross-examined. Q. Is the name like your writing? A. It is certainly an imitation - I am adjutant of the regiment, and sign drafts for recruiting parties; I believe the person who wrote this
James Compton
, wrote this James Hope.

MR. COLLINS. I saw the prisoner write this
James Compton
- he apologized and said, he was a bad writer.

WILLIAM DODD
. I took the prisoner.
(Draft Read.) - 20. 0: 0:
Coldstream Orderly Room, Horse Guards, 27th Dec. 1832,

GENTLEMAN, - Please to pay to Corporal James Compton, of the Coldstream Guards, or bearer, the sum of 20l. which place to my recruiting account. I have the honour to be, Gentlemen, your obedient servant,
JAMES HOPE
.
Captain and Lientenant of the Coldstream Guards.
To Messrs. Greenwood and Cox, Craig's Court, Charing Cross.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Life .

857.
JAMES HALL
and
THOMAS STUBBS
were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the warehouse of
Edward Stubbs
and another, on the 4th of April , and stealing 11 coach-springs, value 22s.; 33 cushions, value 33s.; 3 gallons of japan, value 30s., and 4 carriage-linings, value 4s., their property .

EDWARD STUBBS
. I am a coach-maker , and live at No. 244, Whitechapel-road
; I am in partnership with Mr.
John Dickson Hancock
. On the 4th of April I saw the prisoners in custody of a person in George-yard, which belongs to me and my partner - I gave charge of them; I saw some coach-springs laying about the ground, and some cushions, and varnish in various places on the premises in different parts to where they had been in our warehouse - the hasp of the warehouse lock was broken off.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long before had you been in your warehouse in George-yard? A. We do not often go there - I cannot say that I had been there for several weeks, but if it had been in that state, I should have heard of it.

EDMUND STUART
. I am in the prosecutor's employ; I live at No. 20, Oxford-street, Whitechapel. On the 4th of April, between six and seven o'clock in the morning, I went to the warehouse; I put the key into the lock, and it turned round - I felt some obstruction against it - I pushed it away, and got in; while I was getting some timber, which I wanted, I heard some footsteps - I looked up, and saw a man going towards the gate; I called out; "Who are you? and what do you want?" he went out - I went into the yard, and on returning to the premises again, I saw the two prisoners; I called for assistance, and they were taken; there is only one gate to the premises, which is the one I went in at; some of these articles were taken from below, and some were up stairs; the lock of the gate was not broken, but the staple was broken off; I saw eleven springs on the ground, which had been taken from carriages; I had seen them on the Monday before, and this was on the Thursday; we found thirty-two or thirty-three cushions in different parts, and the linings of four of the carriages appeared to have been cut; I saw a quantity of japan in an iron pot, which had been put there from a stone bottle and a carboy - this screw-wrench was found in the yard.

Cross-examined. Q. How must they have got in? A. I did not see them get in, but they must have got over a wall, or the gate, twelve or fourteen feet high; the prisoners were taken on the spot - two men came to my assistance.
Stubbs. Q. Where did you find the holdfast of the door? A. It was hanging down on one screw; I did not tell you the door had been forced, and show you the holdfast on the post.
MR. STUBBS. I saw the cushions and springs; they were mine and my partner's.

THOMAS OWEN
(Polic-constable H 40). I received information, and found the prisoners on the premises - I have a hand-screw, a crow-bar, and a picklock, which were given to me by Mr. Henry Stubbs.
HENRY STUBBS. I found these things in the right-hand corner of the yard.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you find them? A. On the 4th of April, which was the day the prisoners were taken; I did not produce them on the first examination - I was not there; I did on the second examination.

HENRY BARKER
(Police-constable H 26). I took the prisoners - I found a gimblet in Hall's pocket.

Stubbs' Defence. On the first examination they argued about the wrench, and after we had been committed for a week they brought forward the hold fast, which they forced off, and produced and this crow-bar and key, as they call it.

HALL -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

STUBBS -
GUILTY . Aged 31.

Of stealing only. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

858.
JOHN SOUTHGATE
was indicted for
embezzlement .

WILLIAM WILTON
. I am a bookbinder , and live in New Turnstile, Holborn
- the prisoner was my servant, and was entrusted to receive money . On the 20th of February I sent him to receive money of Messrs. Vizetelly and Co., of Fleet-street - he never paid me 1l. 4s., as received from them.

GEORGE WRIGHT
. I am clerk to Mr.
James Henry
Vizetelly and Co., No. 76, Fleet-street - they are printers. I paid the prisoner 1l. 4s. on the 20th of February, on account of his master; I gave him a sovereign and some shillings.

Prisoner. My master was an oppressive man to me, and I consider this prosecution cruel and unjust; I worked for him from morning till eleven or twelve o'clock at night, and on Sunday till eleven, and had then to go and cultivate his garden; it is a matter of no consequence to me now in what clime I may breathe out the remainder of my existence.
MR. WILTON. I boarded and lodged him, and paid him 2s. or 3s. a week - he never returned to me when he had received this money.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined One Month .

859.
WILLIAM BROAD
was indicted for
embezzlement .

EDWARD HARBUT
. I am a livery-stable keeper , and live at No. 41, Upper Rathbone-place
- the prisoner was my ostler , and was in the habit of receiving money from Mr. Fountain for me; he took the bill to him every week: he told me at one time that the clerk was busy, and he could not get the money.

JOHN DUNN
. I am clerk to Mr.
William Fountain
- he lives at No. 38, Percy-street, and is a wine-merchant; he kept a horse and chaise at the prosecutor's. I was in the habit of paying the prisoner every Monday morning. 1l. 2s. - I paid him on the 4th of March, on the 11th of March, on the 25th of March, and the 2nd of April, and every week - I have his bills and receipts.
Prisoner. I acknowledge it, but you did not give me any chance of paying the money.
MR. HARBUT. I did not know you had got it till last Saturday.

HUGH CARRIGAN
(Police constable S 112.) I took the prisoner - he acknowledged he had received 6l. 12s., and said if I would allow him two hours to go to his father's he would pay the money - I said it was too late.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in trouble, and made away with the first week's money - I could not make that up, and I went on to the last.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 33. -
Confined Three Months .

860.
GEORGE AXTELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April , 9 shillings , the monies of
Jesse Axtell
.

HANNAH AXTELL
. I am the wife of Jesse Axtell - the prisoner is my son; I gave him 9s. and a duplicate to fetch a pair of sheets from Mr. Chapman's, in London-street - he never brought me the money, nor the property, and I did not see him till the Wednesday following.

RICHARD HONEYWELL AVANT
. I am shopman to Mr. Chapman , a pawnbroker. I have the two sheets, pawned in the name of Axtell - the prisoner did not come for them.
MRS. AXTELL. The prisoner was employed to do any thing for me - when he was taken he said he had spent the money at Greenwich fair.
NOT GUILTY .

861.
HENRY WOODHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , 4 live tame rabbits, value 18s.; 1 live tame pigeon, value 2s., and 1 belly-band, value 10s. , the goods of
Thomas Shadbolt
.

AUGUSTUS FOX
(Police-constable N 32). On Saturday the 30th of March, I was on duty in Kingsland-road, and saw the prisoner with a bag. - in company with another man; I went into the tap-room of a public-house where they went - I saw the bag on the table; I asked the prisoner what he had got there - he said, "Some rabbits;" he assisted me in opening his bag, and I saw four rabbits in it - he said he had them from a man in the tap-room, to whom he pointed; the man made no answer - I told the prisoner I should take him to the station; he said he was not in a burry for ten minutes, he should drink his beer - I found a pigeon in the prisoner's pocket.
Prisoner. You never saw me go to the house in Kingsland-road - I told you I bought the rabbits in Hackney, and came down Hackney-road.

RICHARD HAWKES
(Police-constable N 40). I was sent for to the Dutches of York public-house - I saw the prisoner there; I said to him, "Harry, what is the matter?" he said, "Your mate charges me with stealing some rabbits;" I said he must go to the station - he looked at a young man who was there, and I suspected there would be some difficulty in securing him, and I sent Fox for another officer; I saw the prisoner take this belly-band from his pocket, throw it to a man in the tap-room, and the man threw it into the coal-box - when the officer came I took it out of the coal-box; I took this bag out of the prisoner's pocket, and a pigeon, which was dying - this belly-band is marked H. Shadbolt; I found the prosecutor and showed him the same rabbits and pigeon - the prisoner said he got it of the same man as he got the rabbits of

THOMAS SHADBOLT
. I live at Enfield-highway
. I saw the property, and knew it to be part of what I lost from my coach-house last Saturday fortnight, the 30th of March - my house is nine miles off.
Prisoner's Defence. It is impossible I could have done the robbery - I should have been stopped by the Police atEdmonton; I bought them at Hackney of a poor, man who cannot afford to attend.

GUILTY .* Aged 27. -
Transported for Seven Years .

862.
WILLIAM FIELD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 1 brass stand, value 1s. 6d., and 1 pair of tongs, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John James Rippon
.

ROBERT CARRON
. I am shopman to Mr. John James Rippon, ironmonger , Castle-street, Marylebone
. On the evening of the 10th of April I was in the shop, and saw the prisoner take the stand and tongs from the window - he went a little way down the street; I followed him, and took him with them - he said he was very sorry, but he had done it from want.

WILLIAM WALSH
(Police-constable E 54). On the 10th of April I took the prisoner with these things.
GUILTY . Aged 26.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Month .

863.
MARY LINCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , 1 coat, value 18s. , the goods of
William Forster
.

WILLIAM FORSTER
. I live in Bethnal-green. On the 28th of March I went to a house in Church-lane, St. Giles'
- the prisoner and another woman were there; I took off my coat, and laid it in the room - the prisoner took it, and ran off with it.
Prisoner. I was not there at all.

FREDERICK MILSON MILNER
(Police-constable F 63). I produce the coat which I received of a pawnbroker, but he is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

864.
JOHN YOUNG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , 4 keys, value 2s., and 1 stove, value 7s., the goods of
Robert Eckett
, and fixed to a building of his .

JAMES MARTIN
. I live in Noble-street, and am a carpenter; I have the letting of a house in William-street, Clerkenwell
. I lost a stove from there on the 30th of March; I had seen it safe and fixed about five o'clock the same day - there were four keys in different locks in that house at that time - I afterwards saw the stove and the keys in the hands of the Policeman; they were the property of Mr. Robert Eckett.

LEWIS PRICE
(Police-constable G 48). I live at No. 11, John-street. Wilmington-square. On the morning of the 30th of March I stopped the prisoner in Bagnigge-wells-road, carrying this stove; he said he was taking it to Ray-street, for Mr. Hibbert - I took him to the station, and found these keys on him, which fitted the doors of the house, and the stove fitted the place; he was about two hundred yards from the house.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw two men in the street, who asked me if I would do a job; they took me to Chapel-street, and gave me the stove and the keys - they had each of them a parcel; they told me to go to Ray-street.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Confined Six Months .

865.
CATHERINE HAVIS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 25th of March , 6 pairs of stockings, value 1l. 5s. the goods of
Mary Ann Johnston
, well knowing the same to have been stolen .

GEORGE HORNE
. I am shopman to
Mary Ann Johnston
, a hosier , who lives in Tottenham-court-road
; the prisoner was servant in the house . We lost five pairs of silk stockings, which had been near the window; they were wrapped in this paper, which has my writing on it.

EDMUND DAVIS (Police-constable E 86). On the 25th of March I saw the prisoner near Mrs. Johnston's shop; she went in and came out again, and waited some time - her son then came out, and spoke to her; she went in again, and then came out, and I saw her with this bundle; I took her.
NOT GUILTY .

866.
MARY HOLLIDAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , 2 pairs of bracelets, value 1l.; 1 thimble, value 1s. 6d.; 1 thimble-case, value 1s.; 1 knife, value 4s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 2 yards of linen, value 2s.; 2 purses, value 5s.; 1 spoon, value 15s.; 2 rings, value 1l.; 2 seals, value 30s.; and 2 watches, value 6l., the goods of
Thomas Walter Morris
, in his dwelling-house; and that she had been before convicted of felony .

MARGARET FIELDWICK
. I am sister of
Thomas Walter Morris
; he lives at Bromley, in Middlesex
- the prisoner was his servant . On the 1st of March I was present when a box was searched, which was said to belong to her - Mrs. Morris has died lately; I saw found in the box two pairs of bracelets, two purses, a silver knife, a silver thimble, and an ivory case - the other articles were not found: the prisoner said they were given her by her mistress, who was then dead - the articles had been missed, and by her mistress' desire her boxes were detained to be searched; the prisoner was then in the hospital. where my brother had paid a guinea for her admission - I found in her box a pocket-handkerchief, which I know had been my sister's, though my sister's mark has been erased, and the prisoner's put instead of it; the bracelets are worth 1l. - I had been staying there for several weeks; when the prisoner came out of the hospital, she came for her boxes, and I was desired to open them - the articles which were found were in this small box - she owned to the handkerchief being my sister's.

JOSEPH CADRY
. I am a constable. I went with the prisoner to the fever hospital; she desired her sister to bring this little box to her there, but they would not let it come in; I took it back to the prosecutor.

GEORGE COLLIER
(Police-constable N 94.) I have a key which I got at Mr. Morris'; I applied it to a drawer in which this jewellery had been kept, and it was gone - the prisoner sat there crying, and said she knew nothing of it.

ELIZABETH BARNETT
. The prisoner succeeded me as servant at Mr. Morris'; I know the property now produced had been in a drawer in Mrs. Morris' bed-room - my master came for me to go there and I saw this key found in the prisoner's box; she owned she had robbed her master, but hoped he would not prosecute her.
Prisoner. I did not; I said I was quite innocent, and master said if I would confess to taking the watches, he would not prosecute me. Witness. No, he did not; you said you had robbed him.

EDWARD RUBRIDGE
. I lived in the prosecutor's service; I was in the kitchen one morning, and the prisoner showed me a gold watch, set with pearls - she said hersweetheart gave it her, who was gone to the East Indies; she then showed me a headed purse, two or three little purses, and three or four cambric handkerchiefs, which she said her mistress had given her.

MR. FIELDWICK. My sister's was a small gold watch, set round with pearls, and a small lamb in the middle; she had a bead-purse of various colours, which my brother was very uneasy about - I asked the prisoner where it was; she said it was in the drawer to which this key applied, which was the drawer the officer searched.

WILLIAM BURTSALL
(Police-constable V 2). I have a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, at Kingston, on the 26th of March, 1832 - I was present, and know she is the person.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating, that her late mistress had struck her in a fit of intoxication and insanity, and afterwards gave her the bracelets, purses, fruit knife, some linen and a handkerchief, as a compensation; that on her return from the hospital on the 1st of March, she missed several things from her box; and her master accused her of stealing two watches, which she denied; that the prosecution proceeded from revenge on his part, because she would not consent to certain improper proposals,. which he made to her on her entering the service.

COURT to M. FIELDWICK . Q. Did your brother charge her on the 1st of March? A. Yes - I believe he did not intend to prosecute her, if she had produced the watches; she never charged him with making any advances to her - she had only been a fortnight there when she was taken ill; I had not seen the watches for some time - there was a charwoman, but she had no access to the property; I believe a young woman whom the prisoner recommended, attended to my sister, but I was there, the first night I went I had to do some work - I looked for this thimble, and it could not be found; this led to a search for the other things, and they were missed.
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, APRIL 17TH.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Alderman Hunter.

867.
ELLEN WELCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of December , 1 shirt, value 1s.; 1 gown, value 8d.; 2 caps, value 1s., and 1 petticoat, value 4d. , the goods of
Richard Holmes
.

MARY HOLMES
. I am the wife of
Richard Holmes
. On the 23rd of December I lived in Collingwood-street, Shoreditch
- I lost these articles with some bread, butter, tea and sugar; the prisoner was in my apartment at the time - I took her in from charity; the petticoat was found on her when she was apprehended.
JURY. Q. Did you give her any of these things? A. No, nor allow her to wear them.

JOHN WHITE
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner into custody - she had hardly any clothes on: she had this petticoat on.

MARY HOLMES
. This is mine.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

868.
THOMAS WILLIAM PEPPERS
was indicted for that
he, on the 15th of November , feloniously did forge an order for the payment of money , which is as follows, viz:-
20, Birchin-lane, 15th November, 1832 .
Messrs. Williams, Deacon, Labouchere, Thornton and Co., pay Mr. Reading, or bearer, fifty-five pounds.

55. ROBINSON, HAMILTON and Co. with intend to defraud
Robert Williams
and Co
.
SECOND COUNT, for uttering the same, with a like intent.
TWO OTHER COUNTS, calling it a warrant, instead of an order.

THREE OTHER COUNTS, stating his intent to be to defraud
George Brown Robinson
and another.
EIGHT OTHER COUNTS, omitting to set out the instrument.
MESSRS. BODKIN and LEE conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE BROWN ROBINSON
. I am a merchant , and live in the City - my bankers are Messrs. Williams, Deacon and Co. About the end of October the prisoner introduced himself to me by a letter of introduction; he came to my counting-house one day, about the end of November, and asked me if I could negociate bills on his father's house for 150l.; he said his father carried on business at Rotterdam - while he was there stamps were sent out for, to draw the bills on, and they were drawn in my presence - these are the bills which he drew; after they were drawn he asked me if I would be kind enough to negociate them, and give him the money for them - I said, I did not know his father's house; - I made inquiry, and could hear nothing of that house, and refused to advance him money on them - he came again on the 13th (the next day), and asked me to let him have 20l. on the bills, and I gave him a cheque on my bankers for that amount; this is the cheque - he said he wanted the 20l. to go down to Brighton, with a friend; I drew the cheque in his presence, and he wrote his name on the back - I went with him and showed him the banking-house, and left him there; on the 15th he called again, between twelve and one o'clock, and asked me to allow him a sheet of paper to write a letter - I gave him one, and he wrote a letter at the same table as I sat at; he sat opposite to me - my cheque-book laid on the table, at my side; after he had written the letter I had occasion to leave the room, leaving my cheque-book in the place I have stated - I went up stairs, leaving the cheque-book within his reach; this is the cheque-book - my clerk sat with his back to him; I returned in a few minutes - I found him there, and the cheque-book where I had left it; I then showed the prisoner the Bank and Lloyd's, and other places, and, on parting with him, I promised to get him a ticket for the Lord Mayor's ball, which was that night or the next night; there was not the slightest intimation from him that he was going to leave the country - I received information the same day from Messrs. Williams, and, in consequence of a description given me by the clerk, I gave directions that the prisoner should be given into custody; inquires were made after him without effect - the ticket for the ball was to be sent to him at the Royal-hotel, St. James'; application was made for him there, but we could hear nothing of him - this cheque -(looking at it) is not in my hand-writing; I believe the body of it to be the hand-writing of the prisoner - I believe the whole to be his hand-writing; it says 55 pound, leaving out the s; the word pound is spelt in the bills also without the s - the forged cheque is in the same hand as the letter he wrote, which was addressed to Mr. Reading.

Prisoner. Q. At what time on the 15th did we separate in the Poultry? A. I should think about two o'clock - I should think it impossible that the cheque could have been abstracted from my book before that day - I usually left it on my table.
Mr. BODKIN. Q. Can you account for all the two hundred cheques in your book, except this one? A. I can; I had used the book on the 14th.

EDWARD GOLDING ANDREWS
. I am clerk to Messrs. Robinson and Co.; there is only one partner besides Mr. Robinson - the prisoner was in the habit of coming backwards and forwards, I remember his coming on the 15th of November - Mr. Robinson was not at home when he first came; I asked him to sit down, and gave him the newspaper - I sit with my back to Mr. Robinson's table, and cannot see any thing that takes place at the table; Mr. Robinson came in, in about half an hour - I do not recollect the prisoner writing a letter; he was sitting at the table with Mr. Robinson - Mr. Robinson left the office for a few minutes, leaving nobody but me and the prisoner there; he was sitting at the table at the time - I could not see any thing he might do at the table; the cheque-book generally lays on the table - Mr. Atkins does business in our office; nobody else has an opportunity of touching the cheque-book - it is locked in Mr. Robinson's drawer after business hours; I do not interfere with the cheque-book at any time - the prisoner and Mr. Robinson afterwards went out together, about one o'clock; I understood he lodged at St. James' hotel - I lost sight of the prisoner after that entirely; I think I met him once in Coleman-street, but I was not certain it was him, and did not stop him - in February I saw him in Regent-street, I went up to him, and said, "How do you do, Mr. Peppers?" he said, "Very well" - I asked if he had heard from his friends; he said No - I then asked if he was walking about Regent-street; he said No, he was waiting for a friend - I kept him in conversation, and saw an officer in a few minutes; I then ran and met the officer, and brought him to the prisoner - I ran forward and laid hold of him by the arm; he said, "For God Almighty's sake, do not take me!" - he saw the officer, in his uniform, with me; I had told him before, that Mr. Robinson wanted to see him, and asked him to call on him - he said he would next day; I think he was going down Warwick-street when I took him - I did not intimate that I was going for an officer.

THOMAS SHUTT ATKINS
. I am an insurance-broker; I occupy part of Mr. Robinson's premises. On the 15th of November, I cannot be positive that I saw the prisoner there; I could have made use of Mr. Robinson's chequebook, but never did. In consequence of a communication made to me, I went to the Royal hotel on the 15th of November, with two officers; I inquired for the prisoner, but I did not find him.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
. I am a clerk in the banking-house of Meesrs. Williams and Co.; they have an account with Robinson and Co., Old Jewry - the cheques we use have one number through the whole book; each customer has a distinct number - this cheque-book is No. 403; that number was on all the cheques in that book - it contained exactly two hundred cheques; this 20l. cheque was paid in course, on the 15th of November, about four o'clock in the afternoon - this 55l. cheque was brought to our house; it was presented by a man whose general appearance was like the prisoner, but he was in a very different dress - he had a dark frock-coat, buttoned close up; it was in rather a dark part of the office - the person's height and general appearance was like the prisoner; on the cheque being presented I had some doubt of the signature, and went to the back part of the office to compare the signature, and when I returned to the counter the person who presented it was gone - it is an imitation of Robinson and Co.'s signature; the s was omitted in the word pounds - I wrote on it."Differs from the usual signature," and returned it to Mr. Robinson.
JURY. Q.Did you hear the prisoner speak? A. Yes; I cannot say whether the prisoner's voice corresponds - he said he would have gold; he only said the single word"gold."
Prisoner. Q. Are there not persons of similar appearance to myself? A. No doubt of it.
MR. ROBINSON . On the 15th of November, when the prisoner left me he had a dark frock coat on.

ANDREW MOYS
. I was waiter at the Royal hotel, St. James'-street, on the 15th of November - the prisoner was stopping there some time before that; I cannot say when he left - I recollect inquiry being made after him by two or three gentlemen; I had seen him the day before, but not on that day, nor afterwards; I was there for two months afterwards, and never saw him.

WILLIAM HENRY BRUCE
. I am a stationer, and prepare the cheque-books for Messrs. Williams and Co. I made this cheque-book - I have not the least doubt but the cheque in question formed part of that book; I can point out the part of the book from which a cheque has been taken; there were two hundred cheques in it when it was made, and all bore the No. 403; here is the rough edge left from which the cheque has been torn - the margin has since been cut off the cheque, but I can tell from the appearance of the cheque in length and breadth; that it has been in that book, and I speak more positively because only one book was numbered 403; I am certain that cheque has been in that book.
Prisoner. Q. Has the cheque been torn or cut out? A. Torn; the others are cut off at the margin.
The bills referred to being produced had the letter s omitted in the word pounds.

Prisoner's Defence. I am a foreigner, but a consciousness of my innocence has induced me to come to this bar unprotected by counsel or professional advice; I cannot but avail myself of the opportunity of pointing out the very loose evidence to fix the crime on me - it amounts to nothing but that the cheque is drawn in the name of a gentleman to whom I happened to write a letter - and will you consign me to slavery for life for this? can such a coincidence warrant such an act? - conceive the impossibility of my tearing the cheque out, in the presence of the clerk, and that I should be such a madman as to draw it in thename of a gentleman, and leave the letter in the prosecutor's possession.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Transported for Life .

869.
JOHN PARKER
was indicted for
feloniously uttering and disposing of a 10l. forged Bank note, with intent to defraud the Governor and Company of the Bank of England
.

SECOND COUNT, stating his intent to be to defraud
Andrew Eward
.
MR. BULLOCK conducted the prosecution.

ANDREW EWARD
. I am a tea-dealer , and live in New-street, Bishopsgate
. On Thursday, the 14th of March, between six and seven o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came to my shop; I did not know him before - he had my address in his hand, and asked if that was my name; I said Yes - I showed him some teas: he ordered 2lbs. of three different kinds, which came to 1l. 12s. 4d.; he gave me a 10l. note - I refused to give him change, and said I did not know a good note from a bad one; he said no one could refuse a Bank of England note, and told me to try to get it changed; I then took it to the public-house next door, and showed it to
William Tyson
- I returned, and gave him change; I locked the note in my desk - it was the same note as he gave me: I locked the desk, and kept the key - I had no other notes whatever in the desk; I put no mark on it that night, but next morning, about nine o'clock, I took it out, and marked my name and address on it, as I was going to the Bank; this is the note (looking at it) - it is the note I received from him; I left him in my shop while I went to the public-house, to see if the note was good, and when I came back he was gone; he came back in about ten minutes, and had the change - I presented the note at the Bank; it turned out to be forged: I met him on the Tuesday evening, in Long-lane, Smithfield - he was coming towards me; he looked a little wild as he passed me, as if he was startled - I turned round, and looked at him; he turned, and looked towards me, and seeing me standing he took to his heels and ran - I ran after him, and caught him in Bartholomew-close; I am certain he is the man; he caught hold of me by the hand, and said he would pay me - he said, "Don't expose me; I shall be undone for ever - I will pay you."

COURT. Q. Was the tea which he bought weighed out? A. Yes - he took it away with him, and the change; - I took him down Long-lane, and could not find an officer - he got from me twice, but I never lost sight of him; he was secured by Fox - he was rescued from me, and bit my hand- he said he wanted to get away; he was afterwards taken by Hill, the constable.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. When you came from the public-house, you did not find him in your shop? A. No, but he came back in about ten minutes, and I gave him the tea and change; he did not object to my taking the note to the public-house - I did not leave the note with the publican at all; it was never out of my presence.

Q. Did you not say when you met him, "You have given me a bad note," and want your money back? A. No, I did not - he proposed to pay me first; I said he had given me a bad 10l. note; he did not say he was sorry it was a bad one - he said so before the Lord Mayor; I had a load of 18lbs. of tea on my back - I lost sight of him after he ran away first, but not after I took him.

WILLIAM FOX
. I live at No. 6, Rotten-row, Goswell-street. On the 19th of March I heard Mr. Eward call out, and saw the prisoner running at great speed in the road - Mr. Eward tapped me on the shoulder, and asked if I had seen a man in top boots go along - I ran, and overtook the prisoner, and when Eward came up, he put out his hand to shake hands with him, and said, "For God's sake don't discover me, for I am undone - you shall have your money;" I walked behind him, and at the corner of Fan-street he got away - I pursued, and caught him in Brackley-street; he then said to me, "There are others against me - this is not the only one - they can only transport me;" in Golden-lane he told some men it was about a bastard child, and then the men rescued him, and he was taken by Hill.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear him say that? A. Yes, and so did Hill - I lost sight of him in the first instance, but not the second; he did not say he wanted to produce the man who gave him the note.

JOHN HILL
. I am a constable. I was in Golden-lane; I saw the prisoner running, and people after him, crying, Stop thief! I stopped him - he said, "Let me go, it is only for a bastard child;" I took him to the watch-house, and searched him.

JANE WHEELER
. I am niece to Mr. Cummins, at the White Lion, James-street, Bedford-row. On the 3rd of February (Sunday evening) the prisoner came to the house for four bottles of port wine - my uncle asked who it was for; he said it was for Mr. Holmes, No. 25, Great James-street - the wine was delivered to him; he gave a 10l. note for it - my uncle gave him six sovereigns and 6s. change; he was at the bar about five minutes - I asked him into the bar - I am certain he is the man.
Cross-examined. Q. You took particular notice of him? A. Yes, more than I did of the note - he was dressed in a shabby-genteel black coat; I did not notice his breeches - I know him by his features.

JOHN CUMMINS
. I keep a public-house in St. James'. On Sunday evening, the 3rd of February, I believe the prisoner to be the man who came to the bar door, and asked if we sold wine - it was 3s. 6d. a bottle; he said he did not care what the price was so that it was good; when he tendered the 10l. note, I said, "Where is it going to;" he said, "No. 25, Little James-street;" I said,"There is no such number in the street, you must mean No. 25, Great James-street, Mr. Holmes';" he said,"That is the very name;" I wrote on the note, "Mr. Holmes;" this is the note - I wrote it not above ten minutes after I took it; I gave him change - he tied the wine up in his handkerchief and went away; I offered to send my boy with it - he refused; he said I could have the bottles in the morning if I sent to Mr. Holmes' - I sent to Mr. Holmes' next morning for the bottles, and did not get them; Holmes had been a customer of mine.

Cross-examined. Q. You mentioned Holmes to him? A. Yes, my niece was present - she invited him into the bar, and stood facing him at the time, taking a full view of him; I put the note into my pocket, where I had other notes, but I had marked it before I took it off the counter.
MR. BULLOCK. Q. Was it out of your sight before you marked it? A. No.

WILLIAM HOLMES
. I am a solicitor, and live at No. 25. Great James-street. I have occasionally dealt with Cummins - I never saw the prisoner till he was here; I did not send for four bottles of wine to Mr. Cummins', nor did I receive them.
Cross-examined. Q. If empty bottles were called for, your servant would deliver them? A.Certainly.

JOSEPH FREEMAN
. I am inspector of Bank notes. This is a forged note in every particular, paper, plate, and signature, and so is this other - it is of the same description, forged in all respects, and from the same plate.

Cross-examined. Q.Have not forged notes been paid at the Bank? A. I really cannot answer the question, it never happened to me; I heard some years ago of a forged note being paid, but whether it is true I cannot tell; no inspector could take this to be a genuine note
Prisoner's Defence. I have a person in Court who I took the note of.

ROBERT VINCENT
. I am a comb-maker, and live in Skinner-street. I have known the prisoner about two years - I do not recollect every giving the prisoner a 10l. note; I have lent him money several times, but never lent him a Bank note - I have lent him in all about 7l. - he is a horse-dealer; I have been intimate with him, and have dined with him - I lent him 10l. about six months ago, but swear it was not a note; I have not had a note in my possession for some length of time - my wife lent him the last money, but that did not amount to 10l.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Transported for Life .

870.
ROBERT BYERS
was indicted for
feloniously forging, on the 28th of September , a certain order for the payment of 150l., with intent to defraud
Thomas Parkes
and
Joseph Parkes
; against the Statute , &c.
SECOND COUNT, for uttering the same.

NINE OTHER COUNTS, stating it to be with intent to defraud
Lewis Lloyd
,
Samuel Jones Lloyd
, and others.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS PARKES
. I am a hop-factor
, and live in Counter-street, Borough, in partnership with my brother Joseph. I first saw the prisoner on the 26th or 27th of September; he came to inquire for some Farnham hops, for exportation - I told him we did not deal in Farnham hops, only Kent and Sussex; he asked me if I could refer him to any gentleman who dealt in them, and I gave him a few names - there were several samples of hops on our counter; on the 28th of September, he came to our place of business again, and thanked me for recommending him to the other gentleman, and said he had been supplied with the Farnham hops, but he was still open for a few Kent hops, and inquired for some of the samples which he had seen - I told him they were sold; he looked over a variety of samples, and appeared as good a judge as any merchant in the trade; I ultimately sold him ten pockets - he said he should pay cash for them; I asked him to walk into the counting house, and there he gave his name as William, Wallis - this is what he wrote, "
William Wallis
, Sussex-hotel, Bouverie-street;" he asked when they could be weighed - I said not till the evening, and we would send the weight to the Sussex-hotel; this was about two o'clock in the afternoon - he said he should be in the Borough in the evening, and he would call for them himself; and about seven o'clock he returned, our clerk delivered him the invoice, and he examined it, and complained of some little items and the shipping expences being too much, and appeared perfectly conversant with business - he said he had arranged with the Exciseman to come next morning to take the weight of the packages to get the drawback; he then took out his pocket-book, and tendered this draft of 150l. in payment - he gave it into the hands of our clerk; the clerk asked me if he was to give the change out; I said, "No, give a cheque on our bankers," and asked who it was on - the clerk said on Jones, Lloyd, and Co., and the prisoner said, "Oh, it is as good as the Bank of England;" we gave him a cheque for 34l. 18s. 6d. - this is the cheque; the hops could not be delivered until the Exciseman had been - I could not present the cheque that day, as it was after banking hours; the Exciseman did not come next morning - I ordered my clerk to be at Jones' and Co. before the house opened, and be was there; he returned and made a communication to me, and I gave directions to the officers, and sent to Bouverie-street.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. He wrote the direction to Bouverie-street? A. Yes - he wrote it himself; my counting-house is not in the jurisdiction of the City - my firm consists of Thomas and
Joseph Parkes
.

JOHN NEALE
. I am clerk to the prosecutosr. I presented this cheque for payment at Messrs. Jones and Lloyds', on the 29th of September, at nine o'clock in the morning - it was not paid. On the 3rd of October, the draft for 34l. 18s. 6d. was brought to my master's counting-house, or about that time - it has since been paid.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Do you recollect on what day the 29th of September was? A.Saturday; we had received the cheque the previous evening.

GEORGE KERBEY
. I am cashier to the banking-house of Messrs. Jones and Lloyd; we have no customer named Strong, the treasurer to the Globe Insurance Company - they do not keep cash at our house; I know nothing of the drawer of the cheque; we have had, I should think, seventy of these cheques presented at our house, all in the same hand-writing, but different signatures.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Have you paid them? A. No.

WALTER WATTS
. I am a clerk to the Globe Insurance - our treasurer is Mr.
George Carr Glynn
; this cheque is not drawn by any body who has any authority in the Company - we do not keep cash at Messrs. Lloyd's; I know nothing of
William Strong
- we keep cash at Messrs. Glynns'.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.Have you any agent to the Company of that name? A. No; there are from a hundred to a hundred and fifty - I think I can swear there is no agent of that name.
MR. CLARKSON. Q.Have your agents authority to draw cheques on Messrs. Lloyds'? A. None - they have no authority to draw cheques.

JOHN NICHOLLS. I am a waiter at the Sussex Hotel, Bouverie-street. The prisoner was staying at our hotel on the 28th of September (looking at the cheque for 34l. 18s. 6d.) he applied to have this cheque cashed at our house, on the 28th, about eight o'clock in the evening - I refused to cash it, and he left on the 29th, before eight o'clock in the morning - I did not see him again till he was in custody.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he go by the name of Wallis at your house? A. Yes; our house was his true address at that time - he had been two days there.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had you any hops brought there for him? A. No.

THOMAS WILLIAM FARMER
. I am a hop-merchant, and live at No. 79, High-street, Southwark. The prisoner came to my place of business, about half-past six o'clock in the evening of the 28th of September, he showed me the invoice of fifteen pockets of hops, which he said he had purchased on the morning of that day; he produced a cheque for 250l. which I have here - he did not tell me what his name was; he said, "I have come to pay for these hops - here is a cheque of my friend's Mr. Strong, of the Globe Insurance Company, of course you will not object to give me the difference - your cheque will do for the balance, and to-morrow morning, I will send an Exciseman to weigh the hops, and procure the drawback;" I gave him a cheque for the difference on Messrs. Weston, my bankers; I went to Messrs. Weston's next morning, and after I had been there a minute or two, I saw the prisoner there - I think he saw me; I was in the back room, and saw him through the casement - he made his appearance at the outer door, and the moment I saw him, he moved on one side, and disappeared - it was about ten minutes before nine o'clock in the morning; my cheque was afterwards presented at Messrs. Jones and Lloyd's - I have not seen my cheque since - it has never been paid.

BENJAMIN CORBY SWINDELL
. I am a retired major in the army. I know the prisoner, as
Robert Byers
- I am acquainted with his hand-writing; these cheques I believe to be his hand-writing, and so is the address, "Mr. Wallis, Sussex Hotel" - I am under confinement for debt, and am brought from the King's Bench prison; I saw the prisoner in my room there on the 27th of September- he wrote his name as
Robert Byers
then.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you often seen him write? A. Only on the 27th of September; I employed him as my agent, and had numerous letters from him, but without comparing it with them I believe it to be his hand-writing; I am not in his debt - there was a running account between us; he has sold property and paid bills for me at Boulogne - I have never had a satisfactory account from him; he called on me on the 27th of September, and said the person who had my property at Boulogne was likely to become a bankrupt, and I requested him to take charge of my property - I never authorized him to pawn any thing.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you learn from him that he was going to Boulogue on the 27th of September? A. He said he was going that evening - I never saw him afterwards; I received letters from him, and acted on them.

JOHN ROE
. I live at Boulogne. I know the prisoner - he has gone by the name of
Robert Byers
there; I saw him there better than a month ago - I have seen him write directions, but nothing more than five or six words; I have often seen him do that - I cannot swear these papers are his hand-writing; they are similar to what I have seen him write - I believe them to be his writing.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. You never saw him write letters? A. No, only directions to put on baggage; I lived six months at Mr. Starr's hotel, Wood-street, about three years ago - I did not leave him without informing him I was going; I have not heard that he has been looking after me - I owe him 14l. which I lost of his; I went to Boulogne to avoid it - I lost it in an unfortunate house, about eight o'clock at night; I went back to my master that night, but would not tell him of it - I made him acquainted with it through some friends.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I am an officer of the City. I tried to find the prisoner before last September; I took him into custody at Brompton, and took him to the Mansion-house to be examined - I took him on the 23rd of March, I took him to the Compter, and then to the Mansion-house; he was fully committed from the Mansion-house to Newgate; I preferred a bill against him last Friday here - he has been in custody ever since; I apprehended him on another charge, not on this.

The cheque being read, was drawn on Messrs. Jones, Lloyd, and Co. on account of the Globe Insurance Company, and signed" Wm. Strong, Treasurer." The one uttered to Mr. Farmer was drawn in the same manner.

The prisoner, in his Defence, complained of statements made in the public prints respecting him, and that he had not time to bring witnesses to his character from France, but did not enter into the subject of the charge.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Life .
There were two other indictments against the prisoner.
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, APRIL 17TH.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

871.
WILLIAM GOLDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 clock, value 15s., and 1 tea-kettle, value 5s., the goods of
George Richardson
, his master .

GEORGE RICHARDSON. I live in Wyndham-street
, and am inspector to the Imperial Gas Company . On the 4th of April I employed the prisoner to assist in brewing at my house; he began on Tuesday, and continued till Wednesday - I went out at ten o'clock on Wednesday, and returned at half-past two; I then found him intoxicated, and asleep - I desired him not to come again; after he was gone I missed the inner part of my clock, all except the outer case; I went to his lodging on the Saturday evening - he was brought out and taken to the station; I afterwards missed a copper tea-kettle from near where the brewing had been going on; I have lost 200l. worth of property in the last year, since the prisoner has been there.

JOHN HARGRAVE
. I am a gas-lighter, and was employed by the prosecutor in brewing. I saw the prisoner in the brewhouse about two o'clock on the Thursday, when I went out, leaving him and a lad there; the prisoner followed me to a public-house in about twenty minutes, and when he left the public-house I observed a part of the pendulum of a clock in a jacket which was under his arm; I went to the prosecutor immediately, and he missed the pendulum of his clock, which I had had in my hand half an hour before.

THOMAS GREENWOOD
. I am in the employ of the Gaslight Company, and was employed in the brewing. I saw the prisoner near the clock; he had the clock door open - one of his hands was up at the clock, and his other hand had the hands of the clock in it; I asked him if I should put the hands on, and he said No, he would put them on himself; I went into the beer cellar soon after, and ran against something in the dark - I felt it, and it was the prisoner; he asked which way he should go out - I said not through the kitchen, as Mrs. Richardson was there, and he went another way.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not ask you for some beer? A. Yes, and you asked which way you should go out not to be seen.

WILLIAM MALONEY
. I am a labourer, and live in Poplar-place, St. Pancras. On the Thursday evening, between five and six o'clock, I was at work in Portman-street; it rained, and I went into a pawnbroker's for shelter - the prisoner came in with a bundle, part of which was exposed; and I saw it was a clock - he went into the passage, and when he came out again what he had was quite covered - Moran was with me.

DENNIS MORAN
. I live in Seymour-place, and was with Maloney. I saw the prisoner there, and I put my hand to the handkerchief to see what was covered - the prisoner said it was his business, and he would not let me do it - I put my hand to it again; and then he said his landlady seemed inclined to take his effects, and that was his clock, which he was taking away.
Prisoner. That is the truth; it was my clock: I was forced to pawn it for 2s.

HUGH SAVAGE
. I am a labourer, and live in Harcourt-street. On the 23rd of March I was at the prosecutor's, and saw the prisoner go up stairs with a scuttle of coke and a tea-kettle swung round his waist - he then left the premises with the kettle.

JAMES SMITH
. I am a labourer, and live in Suffolk-street. I was at the prosecutor's on the 23rd of March, and saw the prisoner go up stairs with the scuttle of coke, and a tea-kettle swung round his waist - he left the house with the tea-kettle - his jacket hung over it.

WILLIAM HORSFORD
(Police-constable D 6.) I took the prisoner on the 6th of April in Dorset-street; I went into the front kitchen as he was getting out of bed - I told him he was accused of stealing different articles - he said his master accused him wrongfully, he knew nothing of it- I saw a Dutch round-faced clock there, which could not have been removed for some time.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Transported for Seven Years .

872
GEORGE WILLIAMS
and
JAMES ROGERS
were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Elizabeth Lower
, and with a certain sharp instrument striking and cutting her, with intent to kill and murder her .
TWO OTHER COUNTS, stating his intent to be to disable or do her some grievous bodily harm.

ELIZABETH LOWER
. I am the wife of
John Lower
, a tailor; we live at No. 12, Edden-street
. On the evening of the 22nd of February I was sitting in my parlour between six and seven o'clock; I heard a knock at the door; I got up, opened the door, and saw the two prisoners - they both asked if Mr. Lower was at home - I said, No, he was not - Williams then asked what time I expected him - I said it was rather uncertain, as he never came home at one hour - he said, "He is a tailor" - I said, Yes - he said he wanted to be measured for a suit of clothes - I asked him if Mr. Lower knew he was coming - he said No- he then said, "If you will give me pen, ink, and paper, I will write the direction down" - I went into the back parlour to get pen, ink, and paper - they both came into the room - they had at first knocked at my front parlour door, which opens very near to the street door - the street door was shut - they came in some how - I do not know how, but I saw a latch-key afterwards found on Williams - I do not know of any other means they had of getting in but by that key - when they got into the back parlour I had got the pen in my hand, and Williams struck me on the head with a crow-bar, and then Rogers put all his fingers into my mouth, to stop my breath; and said if I made any noise he would murder me with the crow-bar - there were two knocks at the street door the prisoners left me in the back parlour, and went out - they opened the street door, and I heard them say, Go in to the old woman, for she has been murdered" - they said that to Reuben Wheeler, who had given the two knocks at the door - I came out, and cried, "Murder; it is them that came to murder me; there they are; there they go" - Wheeler ran after them, and Williams was brought back by the Police - I said, "You are the man who came to murder me" - my mouth was all pouring out with blood, and my head, where I had received the blow; the blood from my mouth was occasioned by Rogers forcing his fingers into my mouth, to try to strangle me - it was done by main force; it gave me great pain, and I could not eat any thing but what was cold for some time, my mouth was so sore - I feel the effects of the blow on my head to this day; I went to a surgeon, and
Elizabeth Hedges
dressed my head for me - I did not fall quite down, I went down on my side, but not quite to the ground; I stooped with the blow, but recovered my position, and was able to observe them go to the door, and followed them with the blood running down my mouth - the wound in my head bled very much; the skin was a good deal cut - I saw the latch-key taken from Williams in my room, also a knife, and the crow-bar; it is a large knife, which shuts in - Rogers' hand was in my mouth when the knock came at the door; it was almost instantaneously that the knock came to the door.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.What is your name? A.
Elizabeth Lower
; my first husband is dead- his name was Grafton ; I lived with him till his death - I never married Mr. Reading; I do not know the name - I do not recollect seeing Rogers before that night; my house is full of lodgers - a woman named Woodward lives there; I do not know that Rogers kept company with her - I do not know the lodgers' visitors - this was on a Friday evening; I do not know the day of the month - I was very much frightened; it was enough to frighten any body - I had a very narrow escape for my life; I havelived there twenty years - I knew Rogers by his voice and his person; his clothes were dark - he had a white neckcloth on; I never said he had a light drab coat - his clothes were all dark; he had a dark drab long coat - he had something white on his neck.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was Grafton your first husband's name? A. Yes: I never married a soldier - I never knew one; I never married any one but Grafton and Lower - I married Lower here in the City, near Cheapside; I forget the name of the church - it is ten or eleven years ago; I cannot tell what street it was in, nor the parish, nor the name of the clergyman - I could tell if I was at home; I have no certificate - I was married as a widow; I married Grafton at St. Martin's church; I cannot tell how long it is ago - I lived with him three or four years; I married Lower five, or six, or seven years ago - my maiden name was Vaughan; my father's name was Vaughan, but he died while I was young - I do not know my own age; I do not know when I married Lower - I had no friends with me at the marriage.

COURT. Q. Now let me caution you, it is a very serious thing, the lives of the prisoners are in question; upon the solemn oath you have taken, were you ever married to Lower? A. I said I was; I do not wish to swear I was- I do not swear that I was; I have been known by the name of Lower eight or nine years.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was any body present when you received the blows? A. No one but myself. I was sworn to tell the truth, but when I said I was married to Lower, I did not understand the question; I never was married to Reading - I do not know the name; I was never married to any person except Grafton - I never lived with any man except Grafton and Lower.

Q. Now, upon the solemn you have taken) and you may go to Newgate if you tell lies), did you ever live with any man except Lower and Grafton? A. Not live with him, I cohabited with him; his name was Harper, he was porter to a wine-merchant - I do not know whether he is alive or not; I lived with him about nine months.
Q. Will you swear you were not married to Harper? Yes, I was married to him; I cannot swear that he is dead.
JURY. We cannot believe this witness.
NOT GUILTY .

873.
JAMES BAILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of March , 1 chaise, value 20l., and 1 set of harness, value 2l. , the goods of
James Hunter
.

JAMES HUNTER
. On the 13th of March the prisoner came to my shop, and hired a chaise in the name of Mr. Bradfield, for about three hours; he took it away, and I saw no more of him till the 16th - Mr. Bradfield was not a customer of mine; I found the chaise at Putney, on the 15th of March - it was a black gig; I let him have it, believing it was for Mr. Bradfield - he said it was for Mr. Bradfield, of Ropemaker-street; I believed the story to be true, and I parted with it for three hours only - he had a set of harness also.

CHARLES WINSLEY
. I am stable-keeper at the White Lion, at Putney; the prisoner and another man came there on the 13th of March, in a chaise - the other man drove it, and said they wished to put it up there for the night; the other man left the same evening, but the prisoner remained till the 15th - he offered the chaise to me for sale, and to several other persons, to two in particular; and one gentleman had the horse out and tried it - when the prisoner left, he told me to sell it if I could get the price for it, which was 13l.; I asked him if the other person, whom he called his master, should come for the horse and chaise, whether I should let him have it - he said Yes, and asked if I should know him; I said I did not know that I should, for I scarcely caught sight of him - he observed, no one would come for it but the right owner, and I was to let him have it; the prosecutor came down the same night and owned it, and I brought it up to the office the next morning.

WILLIAM ATFIELD
. I am an officer of Worship-street. I took the prisoner on the 15th of March - he told me the horse and chaise were at the White Lion, at Putney, and he had had 14s. or 15s. on it.

CHARLES BRADFIELD
. I live in Ropemaker-street; I never desired the prisoner to get the chaise for me, nor gave him any authority to get it - he borrowed my horse, as he said, to go to Clapham; he went and got the chaise of the prosecutor - I never authorized him to sell my horse.
Prisoner. Q. You lent the horse to Macklin? A. They were both together.

GUILTY . Aged 39. -
Transported for Seven Years .

874
JOHN POUNSFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 4 gowns, value 16s.; 1 pelisse, value 2s.; 2 frocks, value 3s.; 1 table-cloth, value 6s.; 1 curtain and valance, value 1s., and 1 scarf, value 5s. , the goods of
James Knowles
.

SOPHIA KNOWLES
. I am the wife of James Knowles, a law-stationer ; we live in Old Boswell-court, Carey-street
. On the 10th of April I was in my front room, and heard a step on the stairs; I looked out, and saw the prisoner going down the first pair of stairs, with a bundle under his arm - I directly ran to the front window, and saw the prisoner go out of the house and turn a corner; I and my daughter ran down and pursued him; I ran a short distance, and then returned - my daughter went on; he was soon after brought back by Kelly, with the bundle, which contained all these articles; the scarf had been taken from a line in the attic, and the other things were taken from a box, which had been locked, but which I found wide open, and the room door also, which had been locked; the street door is always open, on account of business.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he not say he had found these things? A. No - he did not say any thing to me; I did not observe that he was lame.

ELIZABETH KNOWLES
. I went with my mother in pursuit of the prisoner - I followed him down Shire-lane and Crown-court - I stopped him, but he got from me, and ran down Crown-court and Star-court, which is no thoroughfare - the officer then came up, and he was taken; he dropped the bundle upon me when I first took hold of him; when he got to Star-court he threw the shawl into a dust-hole - I took it up.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you not ask him what bundle he had? A. No - I said that bundle was mine; he said something which I did not understand - it was very fewwords: he then ran away; I did not observe that he was lame - he walked very fast.

BENJAMIN KELLY
(Police-constable F 139). I heard the alarm, and went to Star-court; the prisoner was coming towards me; I found this key on the prisoner - it would not open the prosecutor's door; I went at the solicitation of his wife to No. 5, Crown-street, Westminster, and the key fits his own street door.

Prisoner's Defence. Up to this moment my character has been without a blemish through life - I have a wife and three small children depending on me, and I have now a situation to which I could go and get an honest living.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 43. -
Confined Three Months .

875.
HANNAH ATKINSON
was indicted for
stealing. on the 23rd of December
, at St. Marylebone
, 1 box, value 10s.; 2 watches, value 4l.; 3 seals, value 30s.; 10 rings, value 15l.; 4 brooches, value 2l.; 4 pair of ear-rings, value 2l.; 2 necklaces, value 30s.; 1 purse, value 2d.; 14 sovereigns, 24 crowns, 48 half-crowns, and 80 shillings, the property of
Elizabeth Haydon
, in her dwelling-house : and
THOMAS ATKINSON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .

ELIZABETH HAYDON
. I am a widow , and keep the Flying Horse, in Oxford-street
, in the parish of St. Marylebone - it is my dwelling-house;
Hannah Atkinson
was in my employ as servant
, till the 23rd of December; the male prisoner called on her at different times; I had seen him there three times. On the night of the 22nd of December I took up a rose-wood box, and placed it on a chest of drawers, in my bed-room; it contained about 36l. in gold and silver, two watches, three gold seals, four pairs of earrings, a coral necklace, and two silver snuff-boxes - I am certain there were ten rings in it; there were crowns, half-crowns, and shillings in it - about nine o'clock the next morning I went down, leaving the box safe;
Hannah Atkinson
was then in my kitchen - I went up to my bed-room in about a quarter of an hour, and the box was gone.

SAMUEL WINN
. I am an officer of the Liberty of Ripon, in the West-riding of Yorkshire. I apprehended the female prisoner at Beckworth Shaw, in the parish of Pannell, on the 18th of February - I found on her this satin purse; and the next morning I took the man at Rowcliff, in the parish of Aldborough - I found on him a metal watch, two rings, a coral drop, and some other articles.

Thomas Atkinson
. Q. Upon your oath, who was the person you received these things from? A. You was in the act of putting them out of the prison-window, and telling some children to destroy them: I took them up, and asked him if they were the things his wife gave to him - I showed them to him, he said they were what his wife gave him, he had not stolen them.
Elizabeth Haydon. This is my purse, this necklace, and these three gold rings; this watch and three seals, and other articles are mine - they were all in the box, and locked up.

HANNAH ATKINSON
-
GUILTY Aged 27.
Transported for Life .

THOMAS ATKINSON
-
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before J. Mirehouse , Esq.

876.
WILLIAM OLIVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of February , 1 pair of trousers, value 4s.; 1 coat, value 1l. 10s. and 1 shirt, value 4s. , the goods of
Henry Francis Beverly
.

HENRY FRANCIS BEVERLY
. I lodge in West-street, College-street, Camden-town
. The prisoner lodged in the same house - I left town the beginning of January, and left the prisoner there; after my return I missed these articles- I had taken the coat with me into the country, and brought it back; the prisoner still lodged in the same house - I missed the coat about the 3rd of April; I was not aware that I had lost either the shirt or the trousers, till the duplicate was found.

HANNAH DIXON
. I live servant at the house. I made the prisoner's bed on Monday last, and found in it a purse with seventeen duplicates - I told my master of it.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not leave my room in the morning? and is not the door open? A. Yes, another person might have gone in; I did not know who the purse belonged to.

RICHARD WARNE
. I am a carpenter, and occupy the house in College-street, where the prisoner and prosecutor lodged; on Monday last Dixon gave me the duplicates.
Prisoner. Q. You knew where I worked, and knew my father? A. Yes; you have lodged there six months.

WILLIAM CASSEL
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Camden-town. I have a shirt, pawned by a man who gave the name of John Brown, No. 5, Camden-street - I gave him this duplicate.

JAMES MOODY
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in East-street, Marylebone. This coat was pawned with me by the prisoner for 7s. in the name of George Allen; I gave him this duplicate - it was on Wednesday evening, the 3rd of April, between eight and nine o'clock.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not say, when I was at the lockup place, that you believed I was not the person who pawned it? A. No, I did not; you are the person.

ROBERT HAWKLEY
(Police-serjeant S 1.) I went to the Bell and Crown, Camden-town, last Tuesday night week - I found the prisoner in bed: I awoke him, and asked if his name was not
William Oliver
- he opened his eyes, and said No: I took the candle to him, and said, "I am sure you are the man whom I want, for stealing a great coat, and some other articles:" he said, "Never mind, let it be till morning" - I made him get up and dress; I found a note in one of his pockets - I received these duplicates at his lodging.
Prisoner. Q. I made no resistance? A. No, you did not.

RICHARD WILCOX FAIRLAM
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of trousers, pawned on the 8th of February for 3s. - I do not know by whom, but I gave this duplicate which was found in the purse.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I slept in the back parlour; this gentleman has the front parlour and first floor - I heard of the duplicates being found in my bed, and I was persuaded to sleep out, at the Bell and Crown, not more than one hundred yards from the house.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

877
JOHN THOMPSON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 12th of April , 4 handkerchiefs, value 15s., the goods of
George Lowe
and another, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute .

ENOCH JONES
. I live in the City-road
. I lost a piece of handkerchiefs on Friday, the 12th of April ; we suppose there were six handkerchiefs in it: we sold one, and it corresponds exactly with that found on the prisoner; I am partner with
George Lowe
.

THOMAS CASSEDY
(Police-constable N 71). In consequence of information, I went to the prisoner's house in a court in Hackney-road, between two and three o'clock last Friday; I asked him if any property had been brought to his room - he said No; I said "Perhaps you do not understand what property it is - it is some silk handkerchiefs;" he said "There was no silk brought here;" I saw a hat on the table; I asked him if it was his - he said Yes; there was an old handkerchief over it, I took it off; and found this piece of handkerchiefs in it; I took him to the station, and then I and my brother officer went back to the house, and found this guinea note. this duplicate, and this bottle - this skeleton-key was found on his person.

ALBERT MARTIN
(Police-constable N 72). I went with Cassedy - I found some files, a key, and a centre-bit, in a box, on the ledge of the prisoner's window.

THOMAS APPLEFORD
. I am shopman to the prosecutors; on Friday last I was standing near the shop door - I heard a noise, and a woman pointed to three boys who were then running away; I ran and overtook two of them, but neither of them had any property; they were given to the officer, and they told him where the prisoner lived.

ALAN ZOUCH
. I am shopman to the prosecutors; I have one handkerchief which I bought of them - it corresponds with the piece found.

Prisoner's Defence. The key is of my own room - the guinea note is of no use, it was picked up as waste-paper; I had only been three weeks, and these handkerchiefs were brought by a lad; I am a smith, and the files and centre-bit have been in my nail-box for five or six years; I had been finishing a stove that day, and worked till past my dinner-hour - it was half-past two before I left the shop; I went and got my dinner, and as my wife was not at home, I went up stairs to feed my fancy; the boy had left the property there unknown to me, and he called to know if I was at home.

THOMAS CASSEDY
. The boy took me to the place, and showed me where the property was; he then called to the prisoner that the Policeman was coming; the prisoner took up a poker, and came to the door, but I told him I had my cutlass, and he dropped the poker.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

871
ROBERT SMITH
and
JAMES CARROLL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of March , 11 sheep, price 20l., the property of
Henry Matthews
; 2 sheep, price 4l, and 2 lambs, price 4l. , the property of
James Taylor Murtrie
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

HENRY MATTHEWS
. I am a butcher , and live in Newgate-market; I keep my sheep at Mr. Murtrie's stable, in Sharpe's-alley, Cowcross
. On the 13th of March I was in that stable about eleven o'clock - I had sixty-one sheep there - I took out forty, and left twenty-one; the door was fastened by a padlock on the outside; the next morning I received information - I went and missed eleven sheep; I know both the prisoners by sight - Smith is a master drover; I have not seen my sheep again.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL . Q. Are there not two ways into Sharpe's-alley? A. No - there are posts at the end, which sheep cannot get through well, but I have driven them through; it is not far from Smithfield.

WILLIAM BIRCH
. I am in the employ of Mr. Matthews. On Thursday morning I went to the stable, and saw only ten sheep there - the lock of the stable had been undone, and hung by the staple - I know Smith is a drover.

EDWARD SCALES
. I am in the employ of Mr. Murtrie. On Wednesday, the 13th of March, I was in the stable between ten and eleven o'clock; he had twenty Down sheep and two lambs there - I locked the door; the next morning two sheep and two lambs were missing - I have not seen the sheep, but I saw the lambs at the station; on Friday, we had them and killed them - the officer has the skins; I can swear to them.
Cross-examined. Q. What short of sheep were they; A. Ours were short woolled sheep, some of Mr. Matthews were long woolled.

WILLIAM MLLES
. I am in St. Sepulchre's school. On the 13th of March I was in Sharpe's-alley, about half-past seven o'clock in the evening - I know Smith the prisoner; I saw him about twenty yards from the stable; he was minding some sheep - some of them were long woolled, and one of them had a black face; I threw a turnip among them, and the black faced one eat it - I went for some starch. and as I was coming back I saw Smith again; he told me to go to Greenhill's-rents, and tell the boy there to stop there with the sheep till he came with the lambs; I went there and saw a person - I could not see whether it was a boy or not, but I delivered the message; there were fourteen or fifteen sheep in Greenhill's-rents - on the next morning I went with the officer, and pointed out Smith to him; he had a white dog with a mark round his neck, which had been with him on the Wednesday night.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you live in Sharpe's-alley? A. Yes; only three people keep sheep there - there is one gas-light there; there are not many persons - I saw there was some person with sheep in Greenhill's-rents, and I called over to him.

MR. ADOLPHUS . Q.You noticed one black faced sheep? A. Yes, it came and cat my turnip-tops - there might have been more; I saw a man with Smith, who had a very white coat on, who was doing something at the lock of Mr. Matthews' stable door outside.

Cross-examined. Q.How near were you to the man who was doing something to the lock? A.About twenty yards - I was coming by Smith, who had his dog with him, and after I came back, they both went up Cow-cross.

DANIEL BROWN
(Police-constable G 66). On the 13th of March I saw Smith in Seward-street, Goswell-street, just before eight o'clock in the evening - he was in company with one or two others, who were patting off some sheep; there might be forty of them - one of the men knocked a sheep down, and I spoke to him about it, and said if hedid it again I would take him into custody; Smith said, he knew they were doing wrong, but they wanted to part the sheep; I know Mr. Kimber, in Brudenel-terrace, New North-road - if a man had to drive sheep there from Sharpe's-alley, it would be rather out of the way to be in Greenhill's-rents.

Cross-examined. Q. It would not be a great deal out of the way? A. No; sheep sometimes take a wrong turning, and drovers have sometimes a great deal of trouble with them - it was another man who struck the sheep.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. On the next evening did you take charge of some lambs at Whitchurch's? A. Yes, two lambs - I took them to the station, and they were identified there; they were killed, and I have brought their skins here - on the 15th I saw Smith in Smithfield, driving some sheep, and I took him into custody - I asked what sheep they were which he had in Seward-street; he said the same he was then driving into the market; I do not know the breed of the sheep.

ISAAC BROWN
. I am a butcher, and live in Newgate-market. On the 13th of March I saw Smith in Brick-lane, Goswell-street, at about a quarter or twenty minutes past eight o'clock; I do not know where Mr. Kimber lives, but it is somewhere in the New North-road, more than a mile from Brick-lane; Smith had sixteen or seventeen Down sheep with him - I do not know where they had come from, but he said they had come from Southall-market, and he was going to take them to Mr. Kimber's, in the New North-road; I saw him at the same place again in two or three minutes - he could not have gone to Mr. Kimber's in that time; he had no sheep with him then.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ask him how he came to go that way? A. Yes, and he said to save turnpikes; I spoke to him when I came back, but I did not ask what he had done with the sheep - I think there was a person walking with him at first; I did not count the sheep, there might be twenty-two or thirty-three.

JOHN DISBOROUGH
. I am a chaff-cutter. On Thursday, the 14th of March, I was in Mr. Richards' yard at work, and I saw two lambs come down Seward-street, between six and seven o'clock in the morning; they stopped there about ten minutes, and at last set off up Goswell-street-road; I sent my lad after them - he brought them back, and I put them into Mr. Richards' yard; the Police took them away - they were black-legged ones.

ANN KIMBER
. I am the daughter of Mr. Kimber, No. 50, Upper Brudenel-place, New North-road. On the Wednesday evening Carroll came, and brought twenty-three sheep, as he said, but I did not see them; it was a little after eight o'clock - I gave him a glass of ale.

GEORGE FINDLEY
(Police-constable G 4). I have two lamb-skins, which were taken off the lambs produced at the station.

THOMAS WOOD
. I am a drover. On the 13th of March I saw Smith at Southall-market, and when I came home from Sonthall I saw him in Cock-lane, about a quarter past seven o'clock; there was no one with him, and he had no sheep with him - I went home and left him; I had delivered sixty or seventy sheep at Mr. Venables', about seven o'clock that evening, in Newgate-market - we drew off Mr. Venables' sheep from about twenty-three or twenty-four others, which we left in Cock-lane, in John Graham's care.
Cross-examined. Q. How far is Sharpe's-alley from Cock-lane? A. Just by; sheep might have strayed there - I do not know whose sheep they were which we left with Graham.

JOHN GRAHAM
. I am a drover, and live in Eccleston-buildings. On the 13th of March I was at Southall-market; I saw Smith there, attending for his masters, Mr. Venables and Mr. Kimber - I saw him marking some sheep, he asked me to go home with them, which I did, as he had some beasts to drive home - I left the market before he did, and he overtook me on the road, and passed me about three miles beyond Tyburu-gate; I afterwards saw him near Gray's Inn-lane, Holborn, the same night; I joined him, and we drove the sheep to Cock-lane, where we parted them - Smith drove off seventy-seven, and left me with twenty-three, about a quarter past seven o'clock.

COURT. Q. You were left in charge of twenty-three sheep while Venables' sheep were taken to Newgate-market? A. Yes; these twenty-three sheep were for Mr. Kimber in the New North-road, but I do not know the place.

JAMES VENABLES
. I am a butcher, and live in Newgate-market. On the 13th of March, I employed Smith to bring some sheep from Southall-market; he brought them and delivered them at my premises, from seven to a quarter past seven o'clock - I have a stable in Sharpe's-alley, but I had no sheep there that day.

Cross-examined. Q. Did other persons keep sheep there? A. Yes; three persons - I have employed Smith; his character has been very good as far as I have heard - he had about 450l. worth of my goods on that day.

CHARLES EDWARDS
. I have a stable in Sharp's-alley, and had sheep there that day, but did not employ Smith.

EDWARD SCALES
. These are the skins of Mr. Murtrie's lambs.
NOT GUILTY .

879.
CHARLES HARDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March
, 12 watches, value 50l., the goods of
Betty Armstrong
, his mistress, in her dwelling-house ; and
JANE HARDING
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .

THOMAS ARMSTRONG
. My mother carries on the business of a pawnbroker , and lives in Baldwin's-gardens
; her name is Betty; it is her dwelling-house; I conduct her business for her;
Charles Harding
was in her employ, to assist mostly in the warehouse. In consequence of some suspicion, I charged him on the 18th of March, with stealing some copper money from the cupboard; he hesitated at first, and then denied it, but after some time he said it was of no use to deny it - he turned his pockets out at my desire, and I found on him thirteen duplicates for watches; I gave him into custody - these are the watches; I had not missed them.

ROBERT DUKE
. I am an officer of Hatton-garden. On the 18th of March I was sent for to take Charles Harding; these thirteen duplicates were given to me.

JOSEPH KNOWLES
. I am shopman to Mr. Burlton, a pawnbroker, at Walworth.
