I have a silver watch, pawned by the female prisoner, on the 22nd of February, for 1l.; she brought it in this leather bag - she said it was her own,and she had received it after her sister's death, who had been dead five months; I did not know her before - I gave this duplicate.

GEORGE FRAAS
. I am shopman to Mr. Skinner, a pawnbroker in York-place, Kent-road; I have a silver watch, pawned, I believe, by the female prisoner, on the 5th of March, for 1l. - this is the duplicate I gave; she pawned it for her son John, and gave her name
Fanny Brooke
, No. 3, Salisbury-street.

JOSEPH ATTEWELL
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Kent-place, Kent-road. I have a silver watch, pawned on the 25th of January, by the female prisoner, for three guineas, in the name of Jane Harding, No. 3, Salisbury-street; I believe she said it was her own - this is the duplicate I gave; I have also another silver watch, pawned on the 2nd of March, for 1l. - I gave this duplicate, in the name of
Ann Harding
, No. 3, Salisbury-street.

THOMAS BAKER
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Frederick-place, Old Kent-road. I have a watch, pawned for 18s., on the 13th of March, by a little girl in the name of Ann Harding, No. 3, Salisbury-street; this is the duplicate I gave her.

BENJAMIN SKELTON
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in the London-road. I have a silver watch; I took it in on the 11th of February, of the female prisoner, I believe, for 3l., in the name of
Jane Wells
, No. 4, Salisbury-street, as her own property; this is the duplicate I gave.

WILLIAM LIVERMORE
. I am shopman to Mr. Burls, of King's-road, Walworth, a pawnbroker. I have a silver watch, pawned by the female prisoner on the 11th of February, for 2l.; she pawned it with Mr. Burls, but I wrote this duplicate, and gave her it - it is in the name of Jane Wells, No. 3, Salisbury-street.

HENRY RICHARDSON
. I am a shopman to Mr. Keene, of Holborn, a pawnbroker. I have a silver watch, pawned by some man on the 30th of January, for 2l., in the name of
James Lamb
, No. 22, Charles-street, for his father - I gave this duplicate - I suppose I took it in, as the duplicate is in my writing.

JOSEPH TURNER
. I live with my father, who is a pawnbroker, at Walworth. I have a silver watch which I took in of a girl, on the 13th of March - I lent 2l. on it, in the name of
Mary Vokes
, 2, Pitt-street - this is the duplicate I gave.

JOHN BUCHANNAN
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Roe-buck-terrace, Dover-road. I have a silver watch I took in of the female prisoner on the 2nd of February - I lent 2l. on it in the name of
Jane Wells
, 3, Salisbury-street - I have seen her with watches before, and I concluded she was a dealer in them - she said this was her own property.

JOSEPH CLOTHIER
. I live at Mr. Mullen's, a pawnbroker in Staverton-row. I have a silver watch I took in of the female prisoner, on the 21st of February - I lent two guineas and a half on it - she said it was her own, and gave her name
Ann Hardy
, No. 3, Salisbury-place.

JOHN WATKINS
. I live in Great Sutton-street, and am a watch-gilder. I know most of these watches to be mine - I pawned them at the prosecutor's.

THOMAS ARMSTRONG
. I have missed the whole of these from our stock - Charles Harding had access to the stock; his mother had not.

JOSEPH PRATT
. I live on Great Saffron-hill - I keep a stall, and sell fruit and oysters near to Mr. Armstrong's. I know both the prisoners -
Charles Harding
lived with Mr. Armstrong, and I have been employed by him; the first time was to take a letter to No. 3, Salisbury-street, Old Kent-road, to Mrs. Harding - I went there, and saw the other prisoner - I afterwards took small parcels, four or five times - I received them from Charles Harding - I did not know what they contained - they were directed for his mother, and I took them to her - I never formed the least judgment of what they contained - I received 1s. each time.

ROBERT DUKE
re-examined. I took the female prisoner at No. 3, Salisbury-street - found some duplicates there- I asked her if she had a son who lives at a pawnbroker's- she said she had - I then asked her if she had been in the habit of pawning watches for him - she said she pawned one which was his own - I asked her if she had not pawned more - she at last said she had pawned a good many.

Charles Harding
put in a written Defence, acknowledging the crime; but stating that his mother was unconscious of the manner he had obtained the property, he having stated to her that he received them from a young man, who was a watch-maker.
Jane Harding put in a written Defence, declaring herself perfectly unconscious of the goods being feloniously obtained.

CHARLES HARDING
-
GUILTY of stealing to the value of 99s. only . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

JANE HARDING
-
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
OLD COURT. THURSDAY, APRIL 18TH.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

880.
JOHN MERRELL
was indicted for
feloniously killing and slaying
Mary Rocher Latter
.

JOSEPH CURTIS
. I am a surgeon, and live at No. 12, Union-terrace, Camden-town. I saw the body of the deceased at No. 28, University-street
, on Tuesday, the 2nd of April - the beadle of the parish produced a bottle to me; I smelt it, tasted it, and satisfied myself that it contained prussic acid - there was still some left; the bottle would hold about half a pint - Hutchins, the beadle, produced two other bottles; one of them contained tincture of myrrh - I do not know what the other contained; I saw a-day book produced from Mr. Clapham's, a surgeon, and in that was the entry of a prescription for Mrs. Latter - it was in Latin; it contains no directions for prussic acid - it is a very deadly poison - in the prescription immediately preceding that, there is one containing three drops of hydrocianic acid, which is prussic acid; I believe the mistake arose from there being a dram and a half of hydrosiamus in the prescription for Mrs. Latter, and they are very much a like in writing; they are not written at full length in the prescription - they appear nearly the same, written short, but the difference would be very apparent to a person who examined it minutely; a dram and a half of prussic acid would be deadly poison - prussic acid is like water; hydrosiamus is something of an olive colour - the brother and mother of the deceased described the symptoms, and I consider she died from taking prussic acid, in mistake for hydrosiamus; I did not examine the body internally.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.You cannot tell, I apprehend, from seeing a dead body, whether it diedfrom taking prussic acid? A. Not without examining it internally; the friends would not allow the body to be opened, and the Coroner did not see any particular reason for it - the prisoner was brought before the Inquest to give an account.
Q. The two terms contracted are very much alike, and a boy making up a prescription might mistake one for the other? A. It is possible.

HENRY THOMAS CLAPHAM
. I am an apothecary, and live in Tottenham-court-road. I saw the deceased on Sunday, the 31st of March, at No. 28, University-street; she had a nervous fever, and the tooth-ache; I prescribed for her - the prescription was written in the book, on the 1st of April; I prescribed among other things tinct. hydrosiamus; there had been a prescription immediately preceeding for hydrocianic acid for a patient - there was no prussic acid in what I prescribed for her; I saw her again directly her husband came for me on the Monday, after the prescription had been taken; I found the bottle with the label on it, for a table-spoonful to be taken every four hours - it had been prepared from my shop, and had been prepared by the prisoner; on smelling it, I believe prussic acid to form part of the contents of the bottle; she was hardly in existence when I saw her, the nerves were prostrate; I should suppose she died from the effect of the prussic acid, combined with the state she was in; there appeared to have been prussic acid in the bottle- I cannot say how it came there; the lable was in the hand-writing of the prisoner - she died within a few minutes after I saw her.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Were you there when the medicine was sent out of the shop? A. I was not - I had but one assistant - the prisoner is eighteen years old.

Q. Does he understand Latin? A. As far as I examined him; I did not examine him all through the pharmacopiae; I believe he understands Latin quite sufficiently to make up prescriptions - I never tried him to translate a page of Virgil; I should think I could do it myself; I certainly did not inquire whether he had learned his Latin Grammar - it is a question never asked - I say it ought not to be asked; I gave him no salary - he was to come to me on trial, and 3s. a week was to be given to him to pay the expences of washing until we made an agreement; there is a spaee of six or seven inches between the two prescriptions - Mrs. Latter's follows the other; the prisoner had been nearly a month with me; any one who had vision sufficiently to tell light from darkness, could tell which was which; he has made up prescriptions with prussic acid in them scores of times, and made them correctly; one or two drops is the commonest medicine in the world; I have taken as much pains as any body has ever done; the Coroner's Jury said I had not used due caution in taking his character; I mean to prove to the contrary - I had his character from Mr. Broughton, No. 44, Leather-lane.

JOHN BROUGHTON
. I am a surgeon, and live in Leather-lane. The prisoner was in my service between two and three years - he left two or three months back; I gave Mr. Clapham such a character as I considered he was justified in having - he was not a very well informed young man when he came to me, but being a relation of my wife's I paid particular attention to him; he knew the properties and character of prussic acid.

Cross-examined. Q. How long ought a person to serve his apprenticeship before he dispenses medicines? A. In two or three months a person may make up prescriptions; it would take six or eight months, or perhaps twelve months to make up every prescription - I think it may be learned in that time by a person who did not know Latin; he came to me as shop-boy - I do not know what he had been before; I do not know that he is in any employ before he was with me; he was my wife's nephew - he did not know a syllable of Latin when he came to me; I considered the instruction I gave him quite a sufficient remuneration for his services - I consider when he left my shop his services would be worth 8s. or 9s. a week; he was not apprenticed to me at all - I dismissed him for his impertinence; I never had the least fault to find with him except for that, he acted as servant in my shop and cleaned my shoes, he was not entrusted to make up prussic acid or any thing of the sort - I never had a prescription come into my shop of that sort while he was with me; I am in a considerable business, and did not, in the two or three years, have a single prescription of the kind.
Q. If there had, should you have thought him competent to mix it? A. I should have been very cautious in what I suffered him to do, if I had been there - I took him from the country.

WILLIAM FREDERICK LATTER
. I am a Policeman, and live in University-street. The deceased was my wife - Mr. Curtis saw her; the four bottles produced are the medicine given her by direction of Mr. Clapham - Mr. Clapham saw her on Monday, the 1st of April, after she had taken this medicine; I ran for him in consequence of the symptoms she exhibited - he came directly; she was dying quite fast, and did not live ten minutes - her name was Mary Rocher Latter - I saw three table spoonfuls administered to her out of that bottle; she exhibited no symptoms of dying till after she took that medicine.

MR. CURTIS. This is the bottle which contained the prussic acid - it now smells very decidedly of prussic acid- in my judgment she died from taking the prussic acid contained in the mixture; the dose supposed to have been given was sufficient to cause death, but I would not swear that much less would have done it.
NOT GUILTY .

881.
JOHN TAYLOR
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

ROBERT TILLYER. I am an apprentice to my uncle,
Joseph Henry Tillyer
, oil and colourman , Brentford
. On the 10th of April the prisoner came into our shop - I have seen him before; he said he came from Mr.
James Neill
, a customer of ours, for - cwt. of white-lead, and it was delivered to him, believing he came from him.

JAMES NEILL
. I deal with the prosecutor. On the 10th of April I did not send the prisoner for any white-lead; I have known him for years - he is a plumber's colourman ; he was never authorised by me to go there.

THOMAS BOLTER
. I delivered a - cwt. of white-lead into the prisoner's possession on the 10th of April.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Six Weeks .
NEW COURT. THURSDAY, APRIL 18TH.
London Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

882.
ABRAHAM LUCAS SCOTT
,
THOMAS PROTHERO
,
BENJAMIN CHARLES MURRAY
,
ABRAHAM THOMAS PERKINS
, and
OWEN EDWARDS
, were indicted for a
conspiracy .
MESSRS. ALLEY, GURNEY, and BULLOCK conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM LOWE
. I live at No. 3. Greyhound-place, Kennington: I am a labouring man - I sell birds and fruit when I have nothing else to do. I saw Perkins, the prisoner, on the 17th of January ; I did not know his name then - he came to my house that evening - my wife called me; I came to the door - he asked me if I had a cock linnet to sell; I said I had a very good one; he asked me to let him look at it - I got one, and gave it into his hand; he looked at it, and said it would suit him very well - he said he was going to take it to a friend of his in town, and asked me to walk with him, and he would pay me for it when he had sold it - it was then about six o'clock - he said he wanted to be in town by seven, to meet his friend whom he wanted to take it to, and if he was not there by seven he should be too late; he asked me if I had a cage or a little bag to put the bird into - I said I had a cage, but it did not belong to me, but I lent it him to put the bird into; he tied the cage up in his handkerchief, and we came out together - when we came out at the door, he said he had got a trifle of money for me to take care of till we had sold the bird; he gave it me wrapped up in a bit of paper, and I put it into my pocket; he said, "Don't put it into your pocket, we shall go into a public-house to have a pint of beer, and somebody may take it out" - I said I had no where else to put it; he said I could put it into my hat; I said, "May be I might lose it out of my hat" - he said, "Oh no, you won't lose it - they won't knock your hat off in a public-house;" I then put it into my hat (it was only one parcel), and I put my handkerchief over it - he said, "Let me look if you have put it safe;" I gave him my hat to look at - he said, "It is hardly safe, I will put it safer;" I did not look at it after he had placed it - I had two or three handkerchiefs in my hat, as I generally have; he placed it in, and said it was safe; we kept on the road - he walked on before me, and told me to wait at the Elephant and Castle till he came to me; I waited ten minutes - he then came, and said, "Come on, we have got to go a little further - I have not met the friend I thought of meeting here;" we then walked on till we came near Blackfriar's-bridge, on the left hand side; he there stopped at a gin-shop, and asked me to have something to drink - we each had a penny worth of rum; we then walked on to the corner of Fleet-market - he was there going into a gin-shop again, but he said "I shan't go in here, there is somebody here knows me;" we went on to a watering-house at the top of Holborn-hill; he stopped there, and asked me if I had any money - I said I had three-half-pence; he gave me another halfpenny, and told me to go and get a pint of porter, and stop till he came to me, and he would go to his friend to sell the bird (he had the bird with him); he returned to me in about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, and asked if I was ready to go - I said I had not drank the porter; he took the pot up in his hand, and drank himself - I had paid twopence for it, the three-halfpence of my own and the halfpenny he had given me; he then said, "Drink that up, we will go home directly" - I drank it up in a draught, and in coming past the bar, he said, "Will you have any thing short to drink?" - I said, "I don't want any thing;" he said, "I have just had something myself, and you may as well have something" - I said "I will have a pennyworth of rum, if you please," and I had it; he went to the step of the door, and as he stepped into the street, he called out, "Come on," and as soon as I stepped out, Scott and Prothero came across the road, and collared me: they said, "You have got something you have no business to have, about you" - I said, "I have not done any thing to hurt any body, nor robbed any body - I don't know why you want to take me to prison;" they both said, "You have got something in your hat you have no business to have" - they said, "Don't let him put his hands to his hat," and they kept them down - I said, "If I have got any thing in my hat that I have no business to have, it belongs to that man," pointing to Perkins, who was close to us at the time - I said, "Take that man, it belongs to him - if it is wrong, take that man - what I have got in my hat belongs to that man - take that man;" they said, they had no business with that man, they had information upon me to take me; they then took me to the watch-house, and took off my hat the first thing they did - they pulled the money out, laid it on the bench, and I saw them mark a half-crown and a shilling with a pen and ink - whether there was any more I cannot say - I was then taken to prison, and the next morning before the Magistrate.
COURT. Q. Did you see either Murray or Evans? A. Not till we were at Guildhall.

Cross-examined by PRENDERGAST. Q.Prothero was a Policeman, was he not? A. He was in a Police dress - I do not know whether he was employed in that very part; the Magistrate ordered me to be sent to gaol on a charge of being in possession of bad money; I was there five weeks, and I think I was discharged eight weeks ago to-day, I was discharged at Guildhall by Mr. Alderman Wood; I have been a labouring man all my life - I do not follow birdcatching regularly, only when I have nothing else to do; I have been in regular work - I used to work for Mr. Fenderman while he was alive - I used to work in the brick way - I never was a groom; I have lived about that neighbourhood all my life; when Perkins gave me the parcel, he told me it was money, but I did not know what it was - it was in a bit of paper - I could tell by feeling that it was money, but I did not look at it; I have stated all that he said to me.

Q. Upon your oath, did you not say before the Magistrate, that Perkins said, when he gave you the paper, that he would show you how to make these things? A. Yes; I forgot that - he said "some things," he did not say what; he told me that, not when he gave me the paper, but at the top of Fleet-market.
COURT. Q. You have said some things, was not the expression such things? A. He said some things.

MR PRENDERGAST. Q. Then he did say that to you? A. Yes; I did not ask him what sort of things he meant;I was not anxious to know - I did not ask him any thing; I have now told all that passed, as near as I can recollect.

Q. Do you remember saying before the Magistrate, that Perkins produced to you a bad half-crown? A. No, Sir, he did not produce one to me, nor I did not say so; my wife was in doors the night he came about the bird - I was not there till I was called; my wife was before the Magistrate - there was another person present with Prothero and Scott when I was taken, but I do not know who it was, I was so confused; I have seen Rose to-day - I have heard him say he was there when I was taken, but I do not know; I knew nothing of Rose till this business; we have seen one another every day since this business has been on in this Court, and we have drank on the road; I saw him one evening last week, as I was at work, just by Kennington-turnpike - I was loading a cart; we did not speak to one another for two minutes, as I could not stop - he called once at my house to let me know about coming up to the Session; he did not stop a minute; that was the same night as I saw him on the road - I had seen him at my house once before; I cannot tell when that was - he came down out of the road to my door, and stopped about two minutes; he came inside the door, but the door was not shut - he went into my room; I did not call him, he came of his own accord - he did not bring any message then.

Q. Do you mean to swear, that on that occasion, when Rose called on you, and came into your house, he did not stop more than two minutes? A. It might be two or three minutes - I will not swear it was not ten minutes; we had a pot of beer; we did not talk about this matter - he only asked me how I was, and I said, "I am very well, thank you, I hope you are the same;" he said he only called to see me - I had never seen him till we were up at Guildhall; I did not have any thing to say to him - when he called that day he took a drink of beer, and was off directly; the beer was fetched before he came in at the door - my wife fetched and paid for it; she had taken the money for fruit - I cannot say how long he stopped; I am certain he did not stop half an hour - I do not think it was a quarter of an hour.
Q. Will you swear solemnly he did not stop half an hour? A. I cannot swear what time he did stop.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.When he told you he would teach you to make some things, what answer did you make? A. I made him no answer at all, for he walked on as fast as he could, to meet his friend, but I was close behind him when he said that; I said, "I don't want to learn to make no things of no kind."

Q. How came you tell me this instant that he walked on so fast you could not make him an answer? A. I did make him that answer - he walked on fast; I had no notion what things he meant, not the slightest - I have been in the brick way, gardening, and the like, and in digging.

Q. Did you ever dig in church-yards? A. No; I was never taken up for any thing of that kind - I was never accused of doing any thing in a church-yard, only they give me the nick-name about our place of a body-snatcher - I have heard they call them recollection men; I do not know no more than what I have heard them talk about.

Q. You do not know what is meant by a body-snatcher? A. I really do not know what you mean by a body-snatcher, but what I have heard them say it is body stealing; they give me that nick-name - it is not the name I am known by; they do not say when I go about, "There goes Bill, the body-snatcher."

Q. You have told my friend that Perkins gave you the money, and desired you not to put it into your pocket, for fear you should be robbed - did you ever say that when he gave you the money, he gave it you as security for the bird, and told you to take care of it till he had sold the bird? A. That is what he told me - he gave me that money to hold till he had sold the bird, and I was to take care of it till he came back with the money for the bird - I told the gentleman before what he said; I have given no different account of it to my knowledge.

Q. Now, I do not object to give you the very words - did you ever say any thing to this effect, that Perkins told you most people knew he was a regular smasher, and he did not wish to have the money about him? A. Not to me - he did not say so to me, nor did I say that he did, to my knowledge; I never said so in the presence of Martin, the City officer, nor to any body else. [Martin was here brought in.]
Q. Did you to this man? A. No, Sir, I really think I did not; I cannot give you an answer, Sir, it is a thing that I know nothing at all about.
COURT (reading the deposition)."He said he was well known." Q. Did he say he was a regular smasher? A. No, Sir, I never said so.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You say he said he was well known - was that the reason he gave you the money? A. No; he said when he was going into the public-house, that he was well known there, when he was going to have a pint of porter just at the top of Fleet-market; when he gave me the money he told me to keep it till he had sold the bird.
COURT. Q. Did you ever say, "Perkins asked me to carry the money, because he was well known?" A. No, he did not.
Q. Is this your mark? (handing him his deposition) A. I cannot read; I cannot say, I do not think I made my mark before the Magistrate.

Q. Now he cautious, you were examined before the Magistrate, do you recollect being sworn to what you said, and do you recollect its being taken down in writing? A. Yes, and it was read over to me, but I do not think I put my mark to the paper.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Then you now say that neither before the Magistrate, nor elsewhere, you never said that Perkins begged you to keep the money, as he was well known? A. No.
COURT. (reads) "He (Perkins) asked me to carry the money, because he was well known" Witness Yes.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you not say to-day, that the reason he gave you for giving you the money was, to keep it till he sold the bird? A. Yes, that is very good.
Q.Because he was well known? A. He said that when he went into the public-house.
Q. You first said he gave it you to hold until he sold the bird? A. Yes, that is the reason I say.
Q. Did you not say that he told you he was well known? A. No Sir, I never said that.
COURT. Q. Did you not tell me just now, thatbefore the Magistrate, you used these words, "Perkins asked me to carry the money, because he was well known?" A. No, I never said no such word.

Q. When you were before the Magistrate - did you say "Just as we were coming out of my own door at Kennington, he gave me something in a paper that felt like money?" A. Yes, Sir - I also said, he said, "Put it somewhere where it will he safe;" I said, I had no where to put it but my pocket - he said, "Can't you put it into your hat."
Q. Did you say "I put it in my hat, and he shoved it under the lining?" A. Yes, Sir; I said he placed it after I put it into my hat; I said he said it was to pay bill.

Q. After you had so said, did you not add, "He asked me to carry the money, because he was well known?" A. No, I did not make that answer - Perkins said that when he was going into the public-house - he said he was well known.

Q. Did you say "We came on together, and on the other side of Blackfriar's-bridge, he said he could tell me how to make such things?" A. Yes; I said I did not want to make such things, and he walked on as fast as he could.
MR. BULLOCK. Q. He did say he was well known? A. Yes, that was at the public-house; there is no foundation for my nick-name - people have no right to call me a body-snatcher.

Perkins. Q. You stated that the first drink we had together, I paid for? A. You paid for the first two pennyworth of rum; that was on the other side of the bridge from, here, on the left hand side in coming to the bridge - we had no rum in Farringdon-street.

Q. When you were before Mr. Alderman Wood, did you not say that I told you I would learn you to make these things; that I showed you a shilling, and that I took some soot and salt, and rubbed it with? A. No; I never said no such word about it; I swore I had seen you three or four times before, and no more.

Murray. Q. On Friday night last, between seven and eight o'clock, were you not in a public-house kept by Parker, close by Rose's, with your wife and Rose? A. No, not between seven and eight; we parted with Rose at the corner, just by where he lives - we went to a public-house, and had something to drink going home, but it was not at night, it was in the afternoon.

Q. Did you not go to the fire-place, pull your hat off, fling it about, and say, "Here is the innocent man, and Rose well knows it?" A. I did not; I was not drunk - I have not been tipsy since this happened; I did not call at the Elephant and Castle.

ANN LOWE
. I am the wife of the last witness. I know none of the prisoners but Perkins; I had seen him once or twice before the 17th of January, and on that evening he came about six o'clock - my husband was up stairs with the lodgers; I called my husband down to him - he had not said any thing to me, but he asked my husband if he had any birds; my husband said Yes - Perkins said "Put one in a bag or in a cage, and come along with me, for I know where to sell it for you for 2s. or half a crown;" my husband said he had no bag, but he had a small cage, and Perkins said that would do - (he mentioned that he wanted a cock linnet) the bird was then put into the cage - while my husband was gone to get the cage, Perkins took half a crown out of his pocket, gave it to me, and said, "Do you think this is a good half-crown;" I said, "Yes, it is good as far as I can see, but my eyes are bad" - he then said, "Should you take it?" I said Yes; my husband was then coming back with the cage - Perkins snatched the half-crown out of my hand, turned round, and laughed; when my husband and he were going out of the door, Perkins said to him, "I shall get you to carry this for me, as I am well known and you are not" - I did not hear my husband make any answer whatever; they then went out at the door - I did not see any thing produced when Perkins said this to my husband.
COURT. Q. Was the word Perkins used this or these? A.This; and he said he had some more silver in his pocket, which he should give my husband to carry for him.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Do you know whether he did any thing with the half-crown? A. No - he had not been in my house before, that I know of; he had been to my stall where I sell fruit and a few birds - I have seen Rose to-day, but have not been talking to him - and I saw him when we were at Guildhall on this trial; I have seen him at this Court and at Guildhall, but no where else.
COURT. Q. Did you see him at a public-house last Friday? A. Yes, Sir, at the Rose.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Have you ever seen him at any other public-house? A.Never in my life: I do not know where Rose lives - I never was at his house but once; the Rose public-house is over the way, opposite this Court - we went in there, and had a pot of beer.

Q. Do you mean to swear you have not been in any other public-house with Rose, except at the Rose over the way? A. Yes, Sir, I have been in one very near Rose's house; I do not know the sign - I do not know the name of the street; Rose lives in the Westminster-road, but I could not find his house again - we were never in any other places together than I have named, to my knowledge; I have never been in any private house with him, nor seen him in any private house.

Q. Now, upon your oath, has not Rose been at your own house in company with you and your husband? A. No, Sir, he came to the door, but did not hardly stop one moment; that was the last Wednesday that ever was - he came to tell us that we had been ordered to attend the Old Bailey on Friday, which was a mistake; we were to attend on Thursday instead; he did not come in at the door - it rained very hard, and he said he was out on business; my husband was not at home - he was out loading some road-dirt for a gentleman; he came home a few moments after Rose was gone - I never saw Rose at our house on any other occasion; I am well assured he was not - I cannot recollect whether he did, he is such a total stranger to me.

Q. Will you swear that he did not come to your house, and remain in the house with your husband and you, and that you fetched beer for him? A. I think I recollect his coming one evening, and we sent for a pot of beer, as he said he was dry; I now recollect it very well indeed,but I did not give it a thought before - I think it is a month ago; I think it is since the last Session - I remember his calling, and I was going home with my stall at the time; he sat down a few moments with me and my husband - we did not finish all the beer; I paid for the beer with my own money.

Q. How many persons were these at the public-house near Rose's? A. I am sure I cannot tell; there was my husband and me. Rose and his wife, and I believe his daughter - we all went over the bridge together after we were ordered away from here; they said they were going to have a pot of beer - we had one or two pots.

WILLIAM PAYNE
. I am clerk to the Magistrates at Guildhall. On the 18th of January I took a deposition against Lowe for having bad money in his possession; it was read to Scott and Prothero, and they signed it - there were afterwards two or three examinations, in which Lowe and Rose were made witnesses; what they said is in the depositions.

MR. ALLEY. Q. After the depositions, were made did you hear the prisoners say any thing? A. I have two or three different statements at different times; on the 2nd of February, after the deposition was read over, Prothero and Scott both said they had been led into it by Rose - Evans then said "I know nothing of it; I never had any dealings with the man in my life" - Perkins was there, but he did not say any thing; on the 28th of January Murray only was in custody, and Scott made a deposition against him - Scott said, "I know the prisoner, he came to fetch me to take Lowe into custody; he said, there were two men on Holborn-hill that he suspected had bad money in their possession - I went with him, and he pointed out Lowe, who was standing against the lamp-post; I took him to the station, searched him, and found the bad money in his hat - I have seen Prothero the officer and Murray frequently together; he went with us to Kennington the same evening, when we went to try to find out what sort of a character Lowe was - I never saw the prisoner and Perkins together" - on the 30th of January Perkins was in custody, and Mr. and Mrs. Lowe gave their evidence against him; after the evidence Perkins said -
COURT. Q. Has there been any statement of Perkins' which has been reduced to writing, and signed by him? A. No.

Q. Can you, by looking at that paper, so far refresh your memory as to state that was what he said? A. Yes, my Lord, he said at first he had no question to ask of the witnesses; he then said, that on Saturday Lowe had been tutoring his wife - he said they had been employed by Mr. Powell in several cases, and had received about 30l. from him - he said that
George Roberts
and George Bailey were convicted on their testimony, and he knew a man. named Myers, a tobacconist, at Newington-causeway - Thomas Prothero was then called in, and said that he had seen Murray a day or two before he took Lowe into custody; he did not know Murray's business, but he had seen him with letters cut in iron or steel - he had seen Scott and Murray speak together several times; that they had come together to the Old Bailey - he first saw Murray when he apprehended a man named Carter, in St. Paul's-church-yard - he said further, that he took Lowe soon after he was dismissed, at seven o'clock, when he was going away from duty; he had not seen Murray before he was discharged that day, to the best of his knowledge - that Murray came running up the hill; he said he sometimes had the key of the watch-house, and his partner had it at other times.

WILLIAM ROSE
. I am a butcher, and live at No. 6, Charles-street, Westminster-road. I recollect when Lowe was taken on this charge - I had seen Evans about two months, or nine weeks before Lowe's business - Evans came to my house one afternoon, and said,"Are you doing any business now for the Mint" - I said, No, I was not - he said, "Have you any objection to doing business along with two or three friends of mine over the water, who are two City officers?"- I consented, and said, "When can I see them?" - he said, "If you will be in the way to-morrow evening, from six to seven o'clock, I will call for you" - he called the next evening, and I accompanied him to the Horse and Groom, in Blackfriars-road - he had told me that his friends over the water had plenty of money to go to work with - we got to the Horse and Groom between seven and eight at night, and he introduced me to Scott, Prothero, and Murray - after sitting a little while, he said to Scott, "This is my friend," (meaning me) - Scott said to me, "You have done business for the Mint before, I understand?" - I said, Yes - he then said, "Have you any objection to go into business along with us?" - I said not - he said, "Can you get me a man or two over the water for possession (I understood he meant to have counterfeit money on their persons) - I said I could not get them, I did not know where to find them; but I told him I knew two or three informers on our side the water whom I would introduce to him - that was all that passed then on that subject - I afterwards went to the Horse and Groom again, and I introduced
James Hinton
to all the prisoners, except Perkins - that might be a week or ten days after I first saw them - I went there again just after Twelfth-Day - I saw all the prisoners but Perkins - it must have been between seven and eight o'clock in the evening - the landlady made us a present of two glasses of rum and water, and some cake - I was very often in company with some of the prisoners after that; we had meetings at the Blue Lion - on the Wednesday week before Lowe was apprehended on the Thursday, Hinton, and all the prisoners but Perkins, met there - Evans took me from there about nine o'clock down the London-road, opposite St. George's-market, and told me where to go to call on Perkins; I went there by myself, singly, leaving Evans in the road - I found Perkins at home, without his coat - I asked him to take a walk out with me - he put on his coat, and came out; and I made an appointment to meet him the next afternoon at a public-house at the foot of Westminster-bridge, which he did; and I wanted to see Scott, the bird-catcher, who was to come along with him, but he did not bring him- Hinton came there - I told Perkins I was doing business with two or three acquaintances over the water, and asked if he could find any men - I said I would introduce him to two or three friends; and I introduced him to Murray, Prothero, and Scott, on the Saturday evening (in the week before Lowe was apprehended,) at the Blue Lion - Perkins came to my house on theWednesday after (the day before Lowe was appreheaded,) and said he had got a man ready to come over the water, and he wanted to see Scott - I told him he knew where to find him, and he might go after him - he said he had rather not go over the water by himself; I did not go with him that afternoon, but the next morning I went with him to Scott's, the prisoner, on Holborn-hill: we found Scott on his beat - he went with me and Perkins, and had something to drink - Perkins told Scott he should have a man over, somewhat about six o'clock at night; from four to six - Perkins said he had no money; I told Scott of it, and he gave him 2s., and a sovereign was to be given after the man was taken - Scott said that; in the afternoon about four o'clock, Perkins and Scott, the bird-catcher, came to me in Gloucester-street, where I was killing some pigs at a cook-shop - they called me, and I went into Gloucester-street with them; they told me to be sure and go, and let Scott (the prisoner) know that they would have a man over by six o'clock with possession at Holborn-hill - I went and told Scoot and Prothero, but it was near seven before I got there; I went first into the Blue Lion, and found Evans and Murray there - I then went and found Scott and Prothero both on their beats; I told them there would be a man over directly for possession, and they said they would soon be down - I then went to the Blue Lion, which may be fifty yards from Hatton-garden; it was then about seven o'clock - Evans and Murray were there, Scott the birdcatcher came in, and soon after Perkins came in with a bird-cage but I did not hear any conversation; Scott (the prisoner) and Prothero then came into the Blue Lion - Perkins spoke to him, and then Perkins, Scott, and Prothero went out together - the other remained there; I followed them out, and saw Scott and Perkins on the Hatton-garden side of Holborn-hill - Prothero was over at the watch-house; he then crossed over, and Scott said to me, "You will go with us and assist in taking the man, and witness the case;" I saw Scott take Lowe - we afterwards went to the Blue Lion, and had some refreshment, and Scott (the prisoner) came out with Scott, the birdcatcher, and gave him a sovereign; I heard him say it was to be divided between Scott and Perkins - I did not expect to get paid by them.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. FRIDAY, APRIL 19TH.
London Jury, before Mr. Common Serjeant.

883.
GEORGE ADAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of February , at St. Stephen, Coleman-street
, 1 wooden window-sash, framed and glazed with glass, value 5l.; 2 wooden doors, with sashes glazed with glass, value 10s.; 1 wooden pilaster and cap, value 6s.; 9 piece of wooden quartering, value 9s.; 39 pieces of wooden linings. value 40s.; 8 wooden facias, value 4s.; 9 piece of wooden skirtings, value 5s.; 1 wooden door jam, value 1s.; 1 wooden door stile, value 1s.; 1 wooden door ground frame, value 1s.; 4 wooden shutters, value 10s.; 1 wooden partition, of the length of 26 feet, and breadth of 9 feet, value 3l.; 1 other wooden door, value 2s., and 2 other wooden partitions, value 10s., the goods of the Mayor, Commonalty, and Citizens of London
, belonging to a certain house of theirs; and 1 leaden cistern, in a wooden frame, value 10s.; 1 copper ball-cock, value 1s.; 1 leaden service-box, value 2s.; 200lbs. weight of leaden pipe, value 20s., and 1 other leaden cistern, of 1000lbs. weight, value 5l., their property, and fixed to the said house; against the Statute ,&c.
2nd COUNT, for ripping, cutting, and breaking the said goods, with intent to steal.
3rd COUNT. for stealing the said goods, not stating them to have been fixed to the said house.
MESSRS. ALLEY and GURNEY conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS HERDSFIELD
. I am a City-officer. On Saturday, the 23rd of February, I went to No. 8, Pavement, Moorfields
, about eight o'clock in the evening; I saw a van loaded with wainscoating and wood - I saw that the house looked very bare; I unloaded the van, and put the articles back into the house - I have since seen them fitted to various parts of the house; I found in the house Virgo, Jones, Lowe, and young Poole; I live in the Old Bailey - there were no houses pulling down in the Old Bailey at that time.

EDWARD JONES
. I drive a van. On a Thursday I carried some articles from this house, and on this Saturday night I had got some more, and was stopped by the officer - I carried some boards and fixtures; I did not see the prisoner at the Pavement - I had seen the prisoner at Mr. Poole's yard, in Whitecross-street, and he went with me from there to Mr. Wilkinson's, in Golden-lane; this was on Saturday morning - I carried to Mr. Wilkinson's some leaden pipes; I cannot tell who helped me to load the cart, but the prisoner was in the yard at Poole's, and he went with me from there to Wilkinson's; I had before carried those things to Poole's from the Pavement, but I did not see the prisoner there; I also took a cistern to Poole's, and I took that to the Green-yard - I cannot say on what night I took the cistern from the Pavement; I did not see the prisoner at the Pavement.
COURT. Q. Had he given you any directions before you went to the Pavement? A. No; Virgo told me to take the things from the Pavement.

PATRICK LOWE
. I am a carpenter. I was employed at No. 8, Pavement; I do not know the day - I had been there at work for three or four days before the things were stopped; the prisoner employed me to take down some fixtures there - I took down an iron safe, some partitions, and other things; I took down a cistern, and the prisoner assisted me - I took down some lead pipes, but the prisoner was not there then; I took that down by direction of young Mr. Poole.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was not all this done in open day? A. Yes, there was no disguise about the prisoner; there were four persons at work there; these things were put into a van in the open day - there was no attempt to cover them. I remember the officer coming, and the prisoner demanded to know by what authority he came there - the prisoner said he had a right to the fixtures; he did not give me directions not to hurt the house, but I understood that was what he intended - I acted as I would in any case between landlord and tenant.

CLEMENT POOLE
. I am a willow-manufacturer, and livein Whitecross-street; Mr. Richards is a broker - he employed me, on the 20th of February, to remove certain fixtures from No. 8, Pavement; I was to take them down in consequence of a distress - I am a pretty good judge of what are tenant's fixtures, and what are landlord's - and I removed all that I considered as tenant's fixtures; I saw the prisoner there once or twice - there were two leaden cisterns sold to Mr. Richards by Mr. Pitt; the things that were taken down went to my father's house in Whitecross-street - I thought they were all tenant's fixtures that I took down; I saw the cisterns and the water-closet taken down - I considered them tenant's fixtures; I received a sovereign from Mr. Richards - the shutters had not been opened on the 23rd.

COURT. Q. You took down two cisterns? A. Yes, on account of Mr. Richards; and they were taken to my father's - one was taken from the yard, and the other from over the water-closet; there were three cisterns in all, and they were all taken to my father's.

MR. ALLEY. Q. Did you take down any thing but what was in your inventory? A. Yes, some partition, which Herdsfield said he found in the cart; we took down the window-sash, because Lowe said it would tumble - and some doors were taken down by mistake, to remove some of the articles, and they were put into the van, but not by my order.
Cross-examined. Q. They were taken by mistake, and returned? A. We should have returned them if we could have got into the house.

COURT. Q.What were the partitions you mentioned? A.Partitions in the shop, which I understand were put up by Mr. Adams - I think we were about an hour taking them down; they were wedged up from the floor - there was a sort of leg for them to stand on distinct from the fabric of the house - I understood Mr. Adams was attending there on account of his sisters Eliza and Anna Maria; I did not remove any articles but what I understood were claimed by the tenant - I superintended the removal of every thing; some three-quarter pipe was removed - it was such as would be put up by the tenant, and I have understood since that Mr. Adams put it up; we did not remove the large pipe which carried the water from the roof - Herdsfield came on the Saturday night, turned us all out, and took the names of the persons who were there, he pushed me off the step, locked the doors, and left a man in possession; he said he did not care, he had good backers, and Mr. Adams might do as he liked.

BENJAMIN WILKINSON
. I am a copperamith, and live in Golden-lane. I had seen the prisoner before he brought the lead to my house, which was on the 23rd of February; he had come before to inquire what price I gave - I said 9s. a cwt.; he said, he would send some, and he came with the cart - I asked where he came from; he said he was a dealer, and said, "We are pulling down some houses in the Old Bailey;" there were some lead cisterns cut in two, and some lead pipe - I paid him 5l. for it; he called on me again about three weeks ago, and said, "I understand you want to see me about this lead;" I said, "You have given me a great deal of trouble about it;" he said, "You have mentioned that I told you I brought it from the Old Bailey;" I do not think I made him any answer - he said, "Well, all I want is for a man to speak the truth, for I am sure no Jury can convict me for what I have done;" after I had settled with him for the lead, he said he had another wooden cistern lined with lead, which he thought he should take to the sale-room, as it would fetch more money.

Cross-examined. Q.Was any one present when this observation took place about his pulling down houses at the Old Bailey? A. No; I did not deny to Herdsfield that I had bought any lead - I buy lead every day.
Q.You say the prisoner said "You said that I told you I brought the lead from the Old Bailey," why did you not make him an answer? A. I did; I said, "So you did."

Q. Did you not tell my Lord distinctly, that you made no answer? A. I did not understand the question; when he said all he wanted was for a man to speak the truth, I said certainly, I should do it; my daughter was there - I do not know that she heard it.

JOHN PERRY
. I am an appraiser. I was employed by Mr. Pitt to make an inventory of the goods which had been seized for King's taxes, at No. 8, Pavement - I made an inventory of all that was liable to be seized as tenant's fixtures; there were three leaden cisterns in the house, but only one belonged to the tenant as I considered - we wanted more money, I should have taken more if we could - we wanted 44l., and what we took fetched but 16l. 3s. - I left my inventory with Mr. Pitt.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you leave Poole there? A. I think he was; there were three cisterns on the premises - I think we left two behind; we took only one, there certainly are not two in my inventory - I do not know when the house was shut up; we condemned on the 18th, and the things were removed before the 23rd, I should think.
MR. ALLEY. Q. There was a water-closet - was that a tenant's fixture? A. To all intents and purposes a landlord's fixture.

COURT. Q. Could you at all judge, from the mode in which that water-closet was put up, whether it had originally been put up with the house, or put up afterwards by the tenant? A. No, I cannot tell; it might have been put up by the tenant, but it belonged to the landlord - some fifteen years ago I saw the same water-closet there, because I was then about taking the premises; the ground floor was then adapted for a private residence, and was in Mr. Selig's occupation - it has since been converted into three shops, by putting up partitions, which was most likely done by the tenant; the original front had been taken out, and a court-yard had been inclosed, since I saw it fifteen years ago - I cannot tell how many cisterns were there then.

GEORGE PITT
. I am a broker. My clerk,
John Tomkins
, made a distress in this house, by order of the tax collector; I was not in town at the time; this is the inventory - there is one cistern in this inventory.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean there is only one cistern in this inventory? A.Most decidedly not; I dictated to the gentleman by you what was in the inventory, but I certainly did not dictate to him two cisterns - there was a fictitious distress in the house at the time, and Mr. Poole's son was left in possession.

HENRY CORSE
. I have been in charge of the things in the house since they were brought back by Herdsfield; they are there now - I saw them fitted to the house.

Cross-examined, Q. You were put in by the City?A. I was put in by Herdsfield; Mr. Adams never came and claimed possession of the house, nor any one for him; I never said to Mr. Richards, nor to any one else, that I was in for King's taxes.

GEORGE COLEBATCH
. I am carpenter to the Corporation of London. I saw the things which were brought back from the van fitted to the premises - I saw a cistern lined with lead fitted, it fitted the place exactly - I met Mr. Montague on the 23rd of March there; he told me there were some things at the Green-yard, and he wished me to bring them back - I got a cart about one o'clock, brought them back, and fitted them as near as I could - some of them were tenant's fixtures, and some landlords, but that depends on the clauses in the lease; I should say a water-closet was a landlord's fixture - I cannot tell whose the partitions and skirtings were - I saw some mahogany window-sashes which had been cut to take out the glass: I do not know how old it was - I had never been on the premises before.

COURT. Q. Is not the skirting a ledge of wood put up along the floor, to make the partition flush with the floor? A. Yes, and by removing that and the partition the room would be restored to its former size - they were not the original fabric of the house, they were put up like a screen.

WILLIAM MONTAGUE
, ESQ. The house in question belonged to the City of London - I was there on the 26th of February, in consequence of a statement made to me that there were very considerable dilapidations there - I found the shelves and closets had been removed, a cistern and water-closet taken away, various partitions and some of the doors of the rooms - a mahogany glazed sash had been taken away; the water-closet and cistern were the landlord's fixtures.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not the front sash cut to make a place for a fishmonger? A. It appeared to he cut for the purpose of taking out the glass with more facility - it might have answered for a fishmonger.

COURT. Q. Was not the frame and glass removed in one piece? A. No, part of it was evidently broken, part of the broken sash remained on the premises - the frame part was left, but that which holds the panes of glass in was removed; the shutters were up; if they had not been up, the whole would have been open - the manner in which it was done led me to the impression that it was done for the purpose of taking the glass away.
MR. ALLEY. Q.Was this a part of the house? A. Most unquestionably.
COURT. Q. That shop front could not have been let with the premises? A.Certainly not.

JOHN REID
. I am a subscribing witness to this lease - The lease covenanted that the tenant should give up all the fixtures in the house when he took it, and all which should be subsequently put up; it expired at Lady Day, 1833.

GEORGE COLLINGS
. I am an attorney. I produce the commission of bankruptcy against the prisoner's brother.

Prisoner's Defence. My brother purchased the lease of Selig in 1822 - the premises then consisted of a private dwelling-house, and he contracted with a carpenter in Cullum-street, to alter it into three shops - the centre one he occupied himself; he paid the carpenter 300l., and he laid out about 200l. more, and Mr. Selig had expended 1500l. or 2000l. on it; in 1824 my brother became a bankrupt, but he had previously mortgaged the lease for 300l., and the assignees would have nothing to do with it; my sisters were partners with him in his trade, but he was a bankrupt on his own separate account; the trade paid in full, and my sisters purchased of the assignees his one-third interest in these premises - of course I need not say that, when my brother laid out this money, he had no idea that the City would take them down; but when the City took it in their heads to take these premises down, they gave notice (on the 12th or 13th of February) to the tenants to remove; the object of the tenants then was to dispose of the fixtures, and my sisters employed me to take them down, to sell them to the best advantage; I said, "There are King's taxes due, and the King has power to come in, and, as you are going away, the best way would be for
James Adams
to put Poole in possession" - but the King's tax-gatherer came in, and distrained; I saw my brother, and said, "It is not worth while to stand out - let them take the things;" he agreed not to act; Poole however remained by desire of my sisters; the fixtures were appraised, and my sisters purchased them, and the whole of the property again became my sisters'; we were proceeding to remove them, when, on the Saturday evening, one of the men came to me and told me to go down - I went, and saw Herdsfield; I said, "What is all this about?" he said, "I act under the orders of the City Comptroller - I have orders to stop every thing coming from the premises, and I shall take possession of the house;" he said, "I understand you have stripped the lead off the roof," and he went up to see, but he was afraid to get out on the roof; he said a great many things had been taken away - I said,"We have taken the things we have paid for;" he said he had nothing to do with it, that he was employed by Mr. Hookey; he then asked the men their names, and said, observe, "I do not insist upon their giving their names and address, but I advise them to do it" - I gave mine, and he put it down; he them said, "It is very well you gave your names, or I should have locked you up;" he then said,"The next thing is, you must walk out," and he pushed us out, and left a man in possession - I went to Mr. Poole and was telling him the facts, and in a few minutes Herdsfield came in; he called for a light, which brought out Mr. Poole, who said, "What is all this about?" Herdsfield said, "I am a City officer, I came to see what you have got" - he said his name was Herdsfield; Mr. Poole said,"I desire you to show your authority or warrant;" he said he had none, but he came by order of Mr. Hookey - Mr. Poole desired him to walk out, but I said "We have done nothing that we are ashamed of, let him see what we have;" he then said he was not a judge, but Mr. Montague would come on Monday - on the Monday I was there; the patrol came, and said he came from Mr. Newman, who gave his compliments, and desired that nothing should be removed; I said it should not - the articles were then in the yard; on the Tuesday Mr. Poole was summoned to show cause why he detained certain property; and on the next day he was summoned before Alderman Wilson, to know why these things were removed - on the Saturday I went to the Justice-room, where the witnesses for the prosecution were present; I was ordered to stand before Mr. Ald. Wilson, who read over the evidence of Lowe and another, who had been examined - I said if any chargeexisted, it should be made against myself, as they had been employed by me; he discharged them, and ordered me to find bail, and I was detained till four o'clock. when my friends arrived, and bail was given of two house-keepers, in 20l. each; on the Tuesday I went again before Alderman Wilson, and was examined in a private room; no clerk was present, but the deposition was taken by Mr. Newman, and I was committed for trial - when my brother took the house it was the private residence of Mr. Selig: he divided it into three shops and three separate dwellings, and was obliged to erect water-closets in each of them, and to take water from the yard to supply them, and also a sink and a cistern for domestic purposes - the one which was for himself was on the third story; he made one attic his own kitchen, and carried the pipe from the street to it - there was also a kitchen in the further part of the premises, but no cistern to that; with respect to the cistern in the yard, weighing five or six cwt., it was purchased by my brother when he went into the place - the real fact of the case is, that I was too much of an Englishman to put up with this City possession; and I told Herdsfield I would bring an action against him, and thus they have instituted this charge of felony. But I am here to abide your verdict, and all I ask for is justice at your hands - I ask for no mercy, I have committed no offence.
NOT GUILTY .

884.
SARAH GROVES
was indicted for
wilful and corrupt perjury on the trial of
William Pedley
and
Joseph Smith
.
MESSRS. PHILLIPS and CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

HENRY BUCKLER
, short-hand writer of the Court, read his notes of the evidence given by the defendant, on the trial of Pedley and Smith, for which see First Session, December, 1832 , page 29. The defendant had deposed, among other things, that on the 23rd of June, about five o'clock in the afternoon, she saw a cart backed into the premises of the said
William Smith
, into his yard, and that the gates were shut, and enclosed the cart in the said yard; "and about an hour and a half after she saw the said
William Smith
come out of his yard in another cart with two packing-cases."

RICHARD JOHNSON
. I am a labouring man, and live in Castle-ride, Castle-place, near Castle-alley. On the 23rd of June last, I was in Joseph Smith's premises, who then lived in Castle-alley; there is no number on the door - I was at work on his premises all that day; he had a taxed cart there and harness - I was cleaning the harness that afternoon, inside the gates, in his warehouse or shed; Smith was not at home that afternoon, but there was a cartand a van belonging to him, both at home that afternoon - they never were absent from the premises; there is no entrance for a cart or horse but through the gates, and they were not open all that afternoon - I was on the premises all the afternoon, but at dinner time; if any goods had come and a cart had been backed into these premises, I must have heard it; there was no cart came near the premises in my hearing - there was no room for any cart to have come into these premises for the cart and van which were there; I know Allum - he lived in Castle-place; I cannot tell the number - I know the house; it is up in the corner, in a narrow part.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q.Where do you live now? A. At No. 10, New Market, Finsbury. In October last, I lodged in Castle-ride, Whitechapel; I made an affidavit for Mr. Smith to get him bailed, by desire of Mr. Harmer's clerk - Mr. Smithers went down with me; this was in October last - the trial did not come on here till November; I was here, but was not called as a witness - I came by my own wish, to see my friend done justice by.

Q. Had you stated in your affidavit that you were there all day, that Smith was not at home, and that it was impossible he should have received the goods? A. Yes, I stated it at Mr. Harmer's; I know the premises very well, and no cart came near the premises that afternoon.

Q. Were you ever taken into custody on these pre- premises? A. Yes, I was; I cannot tell the day - it might be on the 25th of June; I was charged with letting a cart out - the man who hired it came as I was going to bed, and wanted a cart to bring a box to the Bull-inn, Aldgate; I do not know whether there was a cart let out, for driving of which, I was charged with stealing goods.
COURT. Q. You made this affidavit - was it for the purpose of Smith being let out on hail? A. Oh no, quite different - it was not to procure bail for him, it was to tell the whole truth.
Q. Was it not that Smith might, by your telling the truth, he let out on bail? A. No, to tell the real truth - I know no other reason.

Q. Now I will give you five minutes before you go into the dock; look at that paper - upon the oath you have taken, was not that affidavit made by you for the purpose of getting Smith let out on bail? - answer that question. A.What question, Sir? I mean to speak the truth.
Q. Do not trifle, or I will commit you to Newgate - Did you make that affidavit in order that he might get out on bail? A. Yes, Sir.

Q. Now I will ask you one more question - When you were stating the facts in favour of Mr. Smith, in order that he might go out on bail, did you mention a word that he was not at home on the 23rd of June? A. I cannot exactly say.

Q. Read it - Now, when you were sworn for the purpose of Smith being let out on bail, did you mention one word about his not being at home on the 23rd of June? A. I said as that represents, and no more.

ELIZABETH WARNER
. My husband is a brewer's servant; we lodge at No. 2, Castle-place - I can see Smith's premises from my apartment. On the 23rd of June I was looking out of my apartment; I saw a large towncart turn up Castle-alley, and it backed down Castle-alley again, to the bottom of Castle-place; it was then very near to my window - it was about a quarter-past five o'clock; there were two large packing-cases in it, two large bags, and a sack - the cases had large letters on them; the first thing that was taken out of the cart was a canvas bag or sack - it was carried to
James Allum
's, No. 4, Castle-place; Allum does not live there now - I have not seen him since Smith was in custody; I had seen him about a week before - the cart did not back at all to Smith's premises; Mrs. Gray is my landlady - she was at her window.

Cross-examined By MR. BODKIN. Q. All this you saw very distinctly? A. Yes, I was at the window when thecart first came down Castle-street - there were two or three men with it; I did not notice whether one bad a whip - there was one man had hold of the horse's head, and two were at the tail, taking out the goods; one of the men took out the bag, and carried it into Allum's - I cannot say whether they knocked at the door; I did not see Allum - I did not see the other packages taken out. I went away from the window - I have lived a year and three months there; I know Smith by sight - I was not at his trial; I did not want to have any thing to say in this business, but I was subpoenaed about a fortnight ago.

RACHAEL GRAY
. I am landlady of the last witness. I was at home that afternoon - I saw a large cart from five to six o'clock - I was in my front room on the ground floor- I saw the cart turn the corner of Castle-place, and go up Castle-alley as far as Smith's gates - it remained there a few minutes, but the gates were never opened - the cart then backed down Castle-alley, and up Castle-place - Allum lived at No. 4, Castle-place - I did not see what was done with the contents of the cart, but it passed my window in ten minutes empty - I had seen two large boxes and a sort of canvas bag in it - I never saw the officer - I saw him bring a man afterwards to measure Smith's gates.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. What time of day did you see the cart? A.Between five and six o'clock - I was at my own window - Mrs. Warner made a remark about it - I saw some men with the cart, but I cannot say how many; there might be two or three; there was one at the horse's head to back it - the cart made a great noise, the stones are very rough there - I do not know whether any one on Smith's premises must have heard it, I never was there - I told what I saw to Mr. Frost, a neighbour, but I was not called on the trial.

COURT. Q.Which way did it pass when empty? A. The same way as it came, down Castle-place, and I suppose down Castle-street, but I did not see it - I had seen it go up Castle-alley as far as Smith's, and then back into Castle-place - I did not tell this before Smith was tried; it might be a week, a fortnight, or a month after he was tried - when I was in at Mr. Frost's, and several neighbours were there talking about it; Mrs. Warner called to me, and said, "Mrs. Gray, do you see that large cart going up the alley?" I looked, and said Yes - I heard of Smith being taken up, but I did not state what I had seen, and I should not have come now if I had not been subpoenaed.

THOMAS ASTON
. I am a gun-locksmith. I was working for Mr.
Samuel Smith
, my master, in Castle-alley, on the 23rd of June - Smith, the man who was convicted, had premises nearly opposite; I saw a cart about half-past five o'clock that day - it had two boxes and a sort of bale in it; it was standing at the bottom of Castle-alley when I saw it - and I heard it go away when I went to my work; Smith's gates were not open when I went by - I did not see what became of the goods in the cart; but I saw a man in the act of unloading it at the bottom of Castle-alley, fifteen or twenty yards from Smith's.

COURT. Q. You saw it unloading in Castle-alley? A. Yes - it stood parallel with Castle-place, in Castle-alley; the back of the cart was towards Castle-place; I never saw it move at all - I was coming from my tea at half-past five o'clock, and saw it stand there - they were unloading it; I am now in business for myself; I heard it go away - it made sufficient noise at the distance of twenty yards for me to hear it.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a carman. I know Mr.
Thomas Elston
. On the 23rd of January I drove a cart for him; after I had finished that job, I met Ellis, and I drove to Dent's, in Friday-street, where I took three packages, which I took to Castle-alley - I do not know what goods they were - Ellis desired me to take them; I did not know that they were stolen - when I got to Castle-alley, they were taken out by Ellis, Wall, and Pedley - the cart stood in Castle-alley; I stood in the cart and delivered the goods to them - no one stood at the horse's head that I know of - I did not back my cart into Smith's premises.

COURT. Q. How near were you to Smith's? A.About ten yards to where the cart was unloaded - I did not see Smith that day; I do not know where the goods went - they went up Castle-place - my cart was No. 152, 884; I have taken it to Smith's premises, and tried to back it in, but could not, there was not room; I saw Groves on the subject of giving evidence; she said to me, when I was in the Pitt's Head, public-house, that I had better say as she did, as I had a large family.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you remember the officer taking you on this business? A. Yes - I told him I knew nothing about the transaction, which I did not, at that time, as I have so many goods in the course of a day; I was taken up three or four months after; I was told what it was for, and I said I knew nothing about it; I told the officer I would tell him all I knew about it; I was taken on a Friday, and on the Saturday I went to Worship-street, and as I said I was willing to tell what I knew, I was allowed to be a witness; I was directed to go to Smith's in Castle-alley, by the man who put the goods into the cart; I received 10s. for my fare.
NOT GUILTY .
